description: Tasty and reasonably priced Chinese food. Husband and I like to get take out from here for a quick & easy dinner. We normally get the pea shoots with garlic, yang chow fried rice, and some sort of meat.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
This used to be our spot our family would go to every weekend!! They must have changed chefs or management because the food is now bland and flavorless. Certain dishes are missing key components; like the fried rice was missing egg and green onions. Tasted very bland and seemed  almost targeting the drunk, late night crowd from Polk. The beef and broccoli also seemed to lack flavor - Worcester sauce was maybe watered down? And perhaps the broccoli was not cleaned thoroughly before being cooked. Cuts of the broccoli were consistent and same goes for beef. The chow mein just seemed like grease and noods
Pretty sad because we loved your last chef and will now need to find a new weekend lunch spot
author: Navila H.

description:
Don't be scared off by the exterior of the building, which is old and almost akin to a haunted house. The food is quite authentic to traditional Chinese comfort food. The mapo tofu was extremely soft and delicious, with heat adjusted by request. The string beans could have been crispier, but the sauce was quite good with tiny prawns and garlic to create an umami effect. The rice was a bit overcooked (maybe a tad too much water?) but not bad. The fried calamari was a bit bland in seasoning, but crispy.

There's a large tv near the entrance in case anyone wants to watch a game. Ample seating. Affordable prices, especially for San Francisco.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Small establishment that serves fresh, fast Chinese food. It's a short walk from our hotel - very convenient! If we come back to this neighborhood and craving food, will definitely return. Service was fast and friendly. There's an aquarium in the back so the fish is still alive before they cook it! Pot of hot tea is given to you along with the menu.
author: Mrs T.

description: I ordered veggie beef chow fun.   It was pretty oily.  But usually chow fun are oily from any Chinese restaurant.  The portion was huge.  Price was ok, everything went up in SF.   I would say this is better than the wok shop on Sutter St.
author: Wei J.

description: This place isn't the same Gourmet Carousel of my youth.  Food was average and pricy for what you get... but this is San Francisco, what do you expect.... everything in the city is gonna be double the price of what it would cost somewhere else!
author: Ben C.

description:
Came here with a group for dinner before an event and I haven't been here in over 20 years!  This place has been around for eons and gets crowded.  A friend made reservations for dinner here for our party of 10.  We ordered one of the set menu dinners for a group of 8 and then added one dish.  

We ordered the set menu which included seafood bean cake soup, crispy fried chicken, ginger/green onion crab (yummy and finger licking good), Peking duck which came with the buns and was pretty tasty, fried quail which I haven't had in ages (crispy and delish), black mushrooms with tender greens, steamed fish, and crystal shrimp with mixed vegetables.  Plus we added bitter melon with beef.  The food satiated our hungry group and there was not much left except for the bones after all was said and done and no leftovers to take home!  We were able to be full for $20 a person which included tax and tip (which is not calculated ahead of time).  Dessert included oranges and fortune cookies.  When I came home I read the health score and I said yikes, and I don't have a cast iron stomach!
author: Karen W.

description:
Gourmet is ALWAYS crackin, no matter what time in the afternoon I come in for takeout. That in itself should tell you that their Chinese food is pretty tasty.

Gourmet has their variety of appetizers, soups, seafood, rice plates, e.t.c.  My co-worker & I usually opt for the broccoli beef over fried rice and the Mongolian Beef chow mein.  These two dishes have tons of flavor and will seriously leave you full.  Just a note, the Mongolian Beef chow mein is a bit on the spicy side. 

I have also tried their vegetable egg roles and salt/pepper spare ribs. WOAH! You definitely need to try the ribs.They are perfectly fried with a great amount of seasoning. I think they use cayenne pepper on them so that can be a but overpowering at times.

Gourmet is pretty reasonably priced.  Keep in mind though, meat substitutes are an extra charge.  For some odd reason they charge you almost an extra $2 to add chicken to your chow mein vs. the Mongolian, PASS! To me, that is a tad bit ridiculous when each dish is about $7-$8 as is.

Overall, Gourmet is a pretty decent value of food and is perfect if your looking for a good tasting, quick meal!
author: Sabrina J.

description:
Definitely some of the best chinese food I have had outside of new york city. The "special" wonton soup is to die for!!

Customer service was great, family operated..and it shows

The fried rice was delightful as well. Heaping portions. I can't say anything better about this place. 



But the best if all was the spicy prawns 




They were sooo good, I thought I would stroke out at any second from extreme pleasure.
author: Danny D.

description: Fresh and fabulous. This food exceeded expectations. The portion sizes were generous, the prices were fabulous, and the restaurant had a farm to table vibe without the attitude. No frills just solid food that allows the fresh ingredients to shine.
author: Stacey F.

description: It's our go to neighborhood Cantonese. Good portions and price. If you can't decide what to have for dinner, family dinner for two or more is perfect. Enough leftovers for next day.
author: Naty D.

description:
Inexpensive and the quality is decent - feel like home cooking - don't think there was MSG.
The only scary part is the low health score ... food tasted clean and non-greasy though. Wonder how they are marinating their meats to get such a low health score.

We also saw the 'Honorable' Ed Lee while we were here. Surprised he would be frequenting this place - super odd part of town for Chinese food.
author: Koalie W.

description: Best pan fried noodles, superior to Hong kong's famous Tsui Wah
author: Sam L.

description: Came here with the family over the weekend and I was not impressed. A friend highly recommended this place and it was terrible. The food was expensive, cold, and bland. The customer service was also ranked up there, pretty bad. We asked for waters and they didn't give our large party any waters until after we got our food because I had asked for them again. They were also really stingy on giving us napkins and straws after asking them a few times. The funny thing was that the restaurant wasn't even busy. They even had the nerve to charge us a service gratuity charge. I wouldn't mind the service charge if we were provided with good attentive decent customer service. Never again. Not worth the high priced entrees for low quality taste food. Not recommended.
author: Mckenzie C.

description: This is a good inexpensive Chinese restaurant.  Their serving portions are large and the food is not salty nor greasy.  Their noodle recipes and egg foo yung dishes are outstanding.  The atmosphere is not great but the service is.  I recommend it.
author: Rob D.

description: The food is always very fresh and flavorful. The service is traditionally curt. Prices are great and the portions are generous. It's always been quite, almost peaceful whenever I've been there. You do get the joy of hearing people in the kitchen yelling at each other in Chinese...then the sound of a bunch of food crashing into the extreme heat of a wok. I have eaten at this restaurant at least 50 times and never even had a mix up with the take-out.
author: Rodney M.

description:
I swear this is one of my family's go-to restaurants for Chinese New Year celebrations, birthday or get togethers. My uncle really likes this place but for the most part, it's pretty standard Chinese food. 

I ordered the hot and sour soup here to compare to other restaurants and this one was more sour than anything. Barely spicy but definitely cleared whatever sinus issues I had! 

Overall, we had a seafood claypot which was alright, the sweet and sour rock cod was interesting. I'd probably go with a salt and pepper rock cod next time. My favorite would probably be the birthday noodles which were yummy. The noodles were almost like hand-pulled noodle consistency. Very chewy! Overall, I know my family enjoys this place but it's just "okay" to me. Not somewhere I'd drive out of my way for.
author: Shelly W.

description: We were in from NYC and hungry, but no energy to explore the neighborhood. We looked on Seamless, and found this restaurant nearby.  We ordered a few dishes, which came pretty quickly.  The food was pretty good for takeout. We ordered simple dishes - fried rice, general tso's, beef with snow peas, etc. Perhaps it would be better to sit down and experience the great ambiance that so many people rave about.
author: Jenn C.

description:
general tso tasted like they used pecan pie for the sauce. 

in their hot and sour soup baby bay shrimp were old and smelled and tasted rotten. 

they had no chow fun noodles, so I had their Singapore Chow Fun which they use Coconut Oil in for seasoning, which tastes sweet and gives a disgusting texture.  

i had one bite and left. paid my full check. 

I sent back the Hot and Sour Soup and they returned with the same bad shrimp. 

I called the health department.
author: Dean N.

description: This place is the BEST. My friend and I stopped in not knowing what to expect but hungry enough to take a risk. Let me tell you it did not disappoint. They serve complimentary soup and hot tea which was a lovely surprise- I love when a meal is more traditional with multiple courses. At the end they serve complimentary fortune cookies and orange slices. I don't know if this is the norm but we went on a Friday evening and it was fast service. I got a chicken entree with a huge bowl of rice for around $11. It was cheap and delicious. My friend got beef and broccoli that was even better and cooked perfect. Highly recommend!!!!!!
author: Ana S.

description:
It's alright i guess. it's cheap, it's suuuuper duper close by, has decent portions, and has a homemade (albeit mediocre) taste. Great if I don't wanna cook.  Not so great if I want a yummy nice authentic Cantonese meal.

I'll give it a few more tries and see if anything sticks out to me.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
My husband and I have been enjoying the food here since about 1983.  It's not fusion or trendy, but it is excellent value, made to order and very good quality.  

The menu is quite extensive. Black bean clams, ginger and green onion crab, lobster lo mein, fried chicken, minced squab in lettuce leaf, fried chicken, ma poh tofu, Peking duck, fried rice, soups, salt and pepper shrimp (with heads), chicken won ton, whole steamed fish, four season green beans are just a sample of our favorites. 

Parking can be challenging, but the Van Ness end of the California Street cable car is only two blocks away. It is also walking distance to the opera house or symphony hall for a quick bargain pre-performance meal.  They also deliver.

I think eating here is one of the things my twins will miss most about going away for college.
author: Joanna S.

description:
TRY their Chef's Specials, they're always great. It's good to try new things sometimes.

I enjoyed their pork-belly dish, the cloud-ear fungus / black fungus dish, lamb claypot, and the bitter melon.

Just have to know what to order. 

I don't think their western influenced dishes were that great, fried chicken w/ sweet syrup lemon or orange flavored, general, sesame, broccoli beef, etc. Tastes all the same. I dare you to evolve your palette.
author: Janno L.

description: I ordered take way. Unfortunately they gave me a deep fried some of animal organ ? I had to dump it because I don't eat stuff like this. I did not feel like waking back to return or get my fried short ribs. Next time check your take away order before leave the restaurant. The wonton soup is pretty good.
author: PerK N.

description:
New favorite Chinese restaurant in SF!! I came here to celebrate a friend's birthday, and everything was fantastic--friendly and generous service, and every dish was delicious! 

We got:
- Crab Meat and Corn Soup
- Peking Duck + Buns
- Pig Skin, Pork Belly, & Rice Noodles Clay Pot
- Pea Sprouts in Garlic Sauce
- Shrimp
- Fried Rice
- Clams
- Pork Pot Stickers
- Rock Cod

This is authentic Cantonese food; you can't go wrong with the Chef Specials menu. The restaurant was very accommodating with our large party :) The menus are well-designed and easy to read, and the restaurant owners were so nice. I'd highly recommend it!
author: Melissa K.

description:
We stopped by here for lunch yesterday after a full morning of errands and hard work. It was close by, inexpensive, and not busy at all. We were seated promptly and given a pot of tea while we went through the menu.

Fair warning to veg*ans: not a lot of veggie friendly options. There's definitely vegetable and tofu dishes, but not a wide range and no fake meat options so be prepared for slimmer pickings than usual. On the flip side though, the food is pretty good and also pretty authentic.

We ordered a green onion pancake to start, along with the bbq pork fried rice and the vegetable lo mein. 

I was surprised when the pancake came out! It was puffy and raised and pretty much hollow inside, unlike the more flat dense pancakes. It was also *piping* hot, fresh from being fried. It was crunchy and delicious! The lo mein came out next and I kind of did a double take... there was easily enough vegetables and noodles piled on there for three meals! The fried rice came out not long after and again, a huge plate of rice and pork bits! We both ate until we were full and still had so much leftover, we asked for containers to go (which we almost never do since we usually don't leave enough to warrant the effort!)  

When our check came? $17 for the whole meal! 

If you're looking for decent Chinese food for a really cheap price, you really can't go wrong here. There's quite a lot on the menu to choose from, although as mentioned above, the vegetarian/vegan options aren't that numerous. I was pretty happy with my meal though and have at least two more meals with the leftovers I brought home.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Cheap and sometimes delicious.
Order delivery several times already. My favorite is their roasted duck with buns, super good! I can eat that all day lol 

Fast service, good Chinese food for days that you don't feel like cooking. I will most likely eat here again.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Okay.... I have yet to have any good takeout place around here in SF.. :( half of the food we ate had either a weird after taste or just tasted funny itself... And long behold, I go on their Yelp to look and they have a warning of being rated in the lowest 5% in health inspection in it's area..... Let's just say, we didn't finish half the food.. Don't wanna risk food poisoning, it just tasted really really off...

SWEET SOUR PORK: this is one of my favorite dishes.. Some pieces tasted like it expired.. It wasn't crunchy.. I thought maybe I had one bad piece.. But 4/5 pieces tasted really bad.. Like not just "this restaurant must do it differently". No. It tasted BAD. 

BITTER MELON: it was still really soggy. Flavor wise I think it tasted okay.. But it wasn't crunchy.. Overall was too scared to finish the rest of it..

GARLIC EGGPLANT: my roommate said this tasted kind of old.. But it seemed like the sauce could sort of mask it.. I thought it wasn't enough flavor even though it had a lot of sauce. 

ROASTED DUCK: this was the only only dish that we kind of enjoyed.. Still greasy like normal takeout. Pretty big portions....

Overall.. This review is about how my roommate and I were too scared to eat the food here. I think if the food tasted fine, we wouldn't have needed to go and read reviews and then freak out over the health notification.. But the fact is that.. The food tasted like it was expired.. And then we read the health notification.. Which lets us assume that the food is most likely and probably truly not good...
author: Tiffany J.

description: Back again for more wonderful food. I had more potstickers because they're just so darn delicious but I really have to talk about one of the dishes from the Chef Specials List, I have had many wonderful dishes from both of the columns, but tonight the Seafood with Golden Tofu in Spicy Sauce just stood out. The shrimp and scallops so tender and the thin slivers of Chinese broccoli in a well balanced, lightly spicy and aromatic sauce are just perfect, try it!- Until we eat again, D.
author: David F.

description: Bad customer service had an eggshell on my food. They where chasing a rat around the store. Demanding a tip. Takes forever to bring your food. Better service to chinese people so if you are not chinese dont bother coming.
author: Carlos M.

description:
Great food and great service.  Ordered catering from them to service about 25 people.  The food was fresh and tasty.  Would love to try out all the yummy food in their restaurant.  

Ordered: 

Fried Wontons
Potstickers
Honey Chicken
Sauteed String Bean 
Buddha Delight
Broccoli Beef
Soy Sauce Chow Mein
Chicken Fried Rice
author: Connie J.

description:
This restaurant, I'm kind of 50/50 about. Never stepped foot inside, but the food I've ordered is so-so. That being said, I've passed by it once, but I wasn't too pleased with the appearance. From the outside, it almost looks like it'd been burned down, but that can't be the case. It just looks questionable.

I started ordering from here solely because I work a couple of blocks away and they're always so quick and consistent with the food. Never takes more than 10 minutes depending on how many plates you order. 

Love, LOVE, the salt and pepper rock cod. Light, salty, but over fried rice it's bomb digs. I can't say I'm in love with the chow mein. I mean, that's usually my go-to dish, but this place kind of ruined it for me. Almost like it's chilling on a bed of oil. I know it's typically oily, but damn, I've never been so disgusted.
author: Tricia M.

description: Gourmet carousel is my go to Chinese restaurant, whether I am eating in or taking out. The portions are HUGE and the service is wonderful. The deluxe  won ton soup is a favorite, and you have to try and so are the chicken dishes. Go to this place and you will not regret it!
author: Steph G.

description:
Tried this place, as my mom recently tried it. She said it was ok and I would agree.

It has some pretty good weird selections, being away from from any of the Chinese communities. And it was pretty reasonably priced.

The one thing I liked was the peking duck. The buns were good and soft. And the flavor of the duck was pretty tasty.

It did seem like the majority of the food is a little on the salty side.
author: Nick N.

description: Yummy! We had the beef with yu choy and shrimp with vegetables. Beef was soooo tender. Classic Cantonese experience complete with winter melon soup as a starter (free) and oranges and fortune cookies for dessert.
author: Resa L.

description:
Great Chinese food at an amazing price! 

Personal favorite is the Beef with fungus, its not as scary as it sounds!

The Salt and Pepper Pork is also top notch, and their wonton soup are hearty and filling.
author: Justin I.

description:
Had a gigantic feast here with my friends and I have to say it was pretty amazing. We had shrimp, clams, duck, fish, pork belly, and a few other dishes, and all of them were fantastic. I left way more stuffed than I had been in a really long time.

Thanks to Gourmet Carousel for a great dinner!
author: Andy K.

description: Best wonton soup everrr. Great value and great service. I'd recommend the crab, the string beans, the fried chicken, quail, shrimp...TBH everything because I've been coming here for 18 years!
author: Lizzie S.

description: Love this place! Awesome Won Ton soup! Quick and cheap! Try the West Lame Soup too. Highly recommend!
author: Rodney D.

description:
OK. I know. I'm trying to judge this place on 30 year old memories. 
So I step back and try to look at it compared to "regular" Chinese restaurants. 

Here's what we had for dinner in a Saturday night. 
Beef stew, tendon, taro in clay pot. Missing that star anise flavor, but meats were very tender. 
On choy hom ha. Vegetable w/shrimp paste. 
Crispy and tender. Too many stems. Not nearly enough shrimp paste. 
General Tso chicken. Light on flavor. Not crispy. Not sweet. Not spicey. Looked good. Good quantity. 
House complementary soup. Good broth and nice melons. Pretty standard in many restaurants. 

All in all, 3 stars. 
Pretty crowded and a good mix of Chinese and Caucasian diners. Chinese contractor types too (usually a good indicator). About 50/50. 

Would I come again?
I definitely wouldn't go out of my way. 
Prompt service and checked in often. 
Maybe for a lunch special.
author: brian k.

description:
"Consumer Alert: Poor Food Safety Score!"
But that's how you know the food is good and authentic...

I've been eating at Gourmet Carousel with my family for years now, and it is still one of the best places for some good old authentic chinese food. Of course they do have most of the generic Americanized food you will find at Panda Express (though don't you dare compare these two places ever) but they also have tons of other dishes you've never heard Tobey Macguire pronounce in a Spider Man movie. 

Many of the older clientele seems like they would frequent the Chinatown neighborhood of the city quite often (a good sign for those 'authenticity' points) and I'm often greeted at the door in Chinese which I don't understand (another good sign - the language, I understand why they greet people). After awkwardly conducting my half of the ordering in English the food always comes out fast and with a smile. And it's good food too, with pretty good portion sizes. I won't pretend to know the names of my family's favorites, and I'm definitely not going to attempt to spell them here, but if you have a friend who can order something other than chow mein or fried rice then definitely try it here! I've found a new-found liking for their pickled mustard greens and squid over rice, something I never thought I would try before. I also love anything covered in black bean sauce and the salted fish fried rice. 

If i'm ordering take out and budgeting my money, I can get 1-2 different dishes that will feed me for at least 2-3 days. Or, if you come with a lot of people, utilize that Lazy Susan and try lots of their dishes! The soups that I've tried are always good at warming you up, and the prices, though they have gone up with the rest of the city, still afford you some cheaper options that to me are well worth the price. 
So be adventurous! Try something new! And always check your place setting to make sure it is clean!
author: Kevin S.

description:
Always the best Chinese food for the money.  The beef and green beans was tasty with lots of meat. The pot stickers here is always better than the other Chinese restaurants with the right mix of veggies and pork. The best dish is the fried wonton in duck soup - not the healthiest of dishes, but excellent.  The dried fried jalapeño pork or chicken wings are ways crispy

The nice thing is they do allow just about any substitution.  Our family always picks this restaurant as everybody has their favorites, and it always hits the spot.
author: Jon H.

description:
GC is your typical greasy spoon Chinese restaurant, so don't come here for the ambiance or expect to be blown away by the food. This place is sort of hidden from all the commotion on Van Ness, tucked away in Lower Pac Heights, so it's a place that services the locals that know of the establishment. I would say the food is decent and gets the job done. 

The menu is pretty basic and has all your typical American Chinese food. Of course with all Chinese places there are items not on the menu that you can ask for, most Chinese people know this.

I would recommend this place to anyone that lives in the area and is looking for some quick and easy Chinese food.
author: Jerry H.

description: I have been here so many times, is it fancy? No. Is it expensive? No. it's good Chinese YES. It's walking distance the school that gave me my PHD in Human Sexuality. regard the health notice, it doesn't scare me, I own restaurant & know what health Dept can do if you don't kiss their asses. I am going there tomorrow with 20 Ladies from China one a billionaire, they love this place, THATS A BETTER RATING THAN 100 of us. TRUST ME
author: Dennis H.

description: Best place for some Chinese comfort food. This place has been around for decades. Still one of the best go to places for Chinese food. Too bad they're too far from my office and home for delivery. I'd order from them for lunch and dinner and office luncheons. Yummy everything.
author: Cathy N.

description:
Gourmet Carousel's fried won ton soups are awesome! 

Hung tao yee foo won ton soup (egg drop soup with imitation crab with fried won tons) - 4/5 - This a slightly thicker soup, like most egg drop soups are. It comes with big chunks of imitation crab and a large back of fried won tons on the side (about a dozen). While you are supposed to dunk the won tons into the soup to soften and eat it, I like eating the fried won tons alone too!  

Shredded duck meat yee won ton soup (shredded duck meat soup with fried won tons) - 5/5 - I prefer this of the two, as the broth is very flavorful (and dark in color) and has little bits of duck. Do not expect big duck pieces like in Roast Duck won ton, it is all shredded. This also comes with large bag of fried won tons and used to dunk into the soup or eaten separately. I like that there is no bones in it and easy to eat. 

Make sure you request yee won ton if you want them fried!
author: Rachelle T.

description: I've been coming to this place for over 10 years and never been disappointed.  Simply put... great value.
author: p w.

description:
I used to live 1/2 a block away but rarely ate there because my wife didn't like Chinese at the time.  Now we live in Miami, and she likes Chinese, but all the Chinese restaurants are horrible and expensive here.  To start out, when I lived on Pine St, they were fast, cheap, and fresh.  You could get a fish lunch special in 2003 for like 5.75.  I went to SF for a corporate conference and I took my friend from Montreal there.  

We started out with the pot stickers, which as somebody else posted, were awesome!  The two main dishes we ordered were Rock Cod, which I asked them to prepare simply steamed with green onion and they put some garlic and ginger.  The Rock Cod was also really good and fresh.  My friend ordered some typical spicy chicken dish that wasn't deep fried with veggies, which was actually really good too! I think Chinese is like Pizza, people order it out all of the time, but it is better to eat very hot and fresh.  We also ordered some Chinese Broccoli, which was decent, but I've had better.  Again, everything was hot and fresh, the service was fast, and the price was reasonable for all the food we ordered.
author: Terrence G.

description: Great basic Chinese restaurant. Try the salt & pepper shrimp if you don't mind having to remove the shell. Delicious! Great shrimp wonton soup. I also like their pot stickers, pea sprouts with garlic and almost anything with pork!
author: Lauren H.

description: Consistently great Chinese food. Friendly service and great place for small groups too. Beef with fungus, Egg Foo Young (the best in the city), Crab, salt and pepper prawns, Hong Kong style pan fried noodles. Been going here for 20+ years. Parking may be a challenge, but if you time it right at 6pm, the no stopping lane on Franklin opens up!
author: Leon L.

description:
I updated my review by one star,the food was quite good,they put up the food prices by $2 so the place was half empty at lunch,i think this has made the food taste better as there was less pressure on the cooks,i think they have cleaned up the health problems,food tastes much better than before,i had the egg and beef over rice,which was good,probably better than most places I have ate in,prices increased by $2 but its still cheap for lunchabout$7-$7.50
service is still friendly I will go back there,portions are still big,all in all I was happy with the place
author: cc c.

description:
My family used to come here all the time. I have no idea why since we lived in the Sunset District and there is no shortage of Chinese restaurants there.    Your standard Chinese restaurant with reasonable prices, big portions and pretty solid food.  People who complain about this place probably think PF Chang is authentic chinese food and probably happily pay $30 for a piece of quail on artisan bread garnished with daikon.

This was my dad's favorite place. RIP Dad... that is worth 5 stars automatically.
author: Jason Y.

description: The egg rolls were crisp and delicious, but the sauce they come with is very sweet and looks like jam.  The prawn and noodles tasted ok but there were only 3-4 prawns!  The broccoli and oyster sauce had no flavor at all, was there supposed to be a flavor in the sauce?  The Singapore noodles tasted fine, but had a strange crumbly texture. On top of that the bottle of Orangina I ordered was nearly impossible to open.
author: Lynne A.

description:
Fast service and yummy food that I didn't find too greasy or heavy, it was perfect for lunch, even with a big group. 

My co-worker and I shared a BBQ pork wonton soup (it was HUGE) and most of all, so soothing to the tummy in cold weather. We also shared this big ole rice plate of salt and pepper prawns. They're not shy about giving lots of rice, which is good for leftovers later on for dinner. 

The prawns were fried and not too oily, I even ate the head for the first time. I've been missing out all this time! Super crispy, good flavor and texture.

I like how although the place is extremely busy, they continue to serve you, never forget you and it's always fast, but not rushed at all.

The price was awesome. I paid less than $10 for my share and I was more than content with my lunch.

Can't wait to come back!
author: Sharon B.

description: cheap and fast!   Love this place.  I usually order the prawns & scrambled eggs over rice.
author: Mikky T.

description: I came here as a kid with my parents and aunt's family. I came here again with my parents to celebrate my dad's birthday. It was an one hour walk from my work. I had a very big appetite by the time I arrived! They gave us some menus, but I asked where is the family dinner menu? Good thing I asked! There is a seafood combo for $48 estimated to feed 4 people. It comes with a tofu and seafood soup, black bean clams, scallop and shrimp dish with vegetables,  salt and pepper shrimp, a really big whole fish, and fortune cookies and oranges. Everything was very delicious. The only thing I didn't like is we didn't order rice, but he assumed we did and bought it. I thought it came with the meal, but we got charged for it. That's not right because what if we didn't want to eat rice. As we're facing a drought now, I also thought that it's unnecessary to give us a second dish without asking. Our dishes weren't full of seafood shells yet. Besides these two assumptions, everything else was great.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Cheap food is really all this place has going for it.

I came here a few times with coworkers since it's somewhat close to the office. Each time, we always had at least one plate and/or utensil which was poorly cleaned. Not a great way to start, but luckily since the place is never packed, we just switch it off with another table's set. Sorry to whoever came in after us...

We would have groups of around ten people, but within five minutes of ordering, somehow we would all have our orders arrive. It really seems the food was pre-cooked and then thrown in a microwave. The rice they serve kinda proves it, being somewhat cold and chunky. You would think that they would at least have a giant rice cooker to serve something fresh.

The extra star is for the low cost. I'm a fan of simple Chinese dishes but that doesn't mean the chefs can get away with putting no effort into them.
author: Allen C.

description:
Really good chinese food. This is really long overdue review. Been going here for years and it has good food for really good prices. 

Lunch specials like the rice plates are good and they play the giants game if it's on
author: Kenjo H.

description:
All that you can't leave behind.

Highly acclaimed album: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_that_you_can%27t_leave_behind

Highly acclaimed dish: Baked lobster in black bean sauce.

Really loved the former back in college. Can't say I loved the former earlier tonight.

Trying to make up my mind was steered this way by the friendly staff saying they sell upwards of thirty a night. Sometimes it is better to go with the crowd.

Arriving home two things were disappointing:

1. Had no tools to crack the lobster. It was my own stupid fault. Twenty minutes of pierced fingers later had my crustacean. Much was left behind.

2. Impressed by the amount (especially for the $12.99 + tax price) and bonus veggie pieces, but not by the excessively oily black bean sauce. Should have left more behind.

Hard to give less than three stars for so much lobster at such a great price by a friendly staff. Little healthier overall and a fourth star wouldn't have been left behind.

Five stars however goes to the inspiration for tonight's Chinese food adventure. Much respect David and good luck: http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-chinese-eater-20130422-dto,0,6902048.htmlstory#readmore
author: Jason B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. When we sat down the food looked good. We started with the potstickers, which were delicious. Then came the main course: The green beans were dry and salty, the chicken fried rice was made with little baby shrimp rather than chicken and also dry and tasteless. The orange chicken was way over cooked and the sauce tasted like it came from a can. The honey shrimp with walnuts was OK, and the tea was good. 

The good: The people were friendly and the food was served in a timely manner. Don't forget the potstickers, those were very good.
author: Stephanie S.

description: We order take out from here about once a week.  Delivery is always friendly and quick ($30 minimum order).  The food is always fresh and hot.  It is not overly spicy, but taste delicious.  I recommend Gourmet Carousel!
author: R F.

description:
Ordered my usual which was the Preserved pickle with shredded porkrice noodle. Highly recommended, the soup and noodle tasted wonderful, and very little pork meat so it's healthy.

Bitter melon chicken is my 2nd favorite. Only if you enjoy bitter melon, which is not for everyone.
author: Daniel W.

description: I ordered the radish and beef stew in clay pot. It is the best I've ever tried outside of China. It comes with a veggie soup, which is really tasty
author: Mian F.

description: I walked in at night since I saw the "Open" neon sign on. I ask the owner for a soup to go and he tells me, "We're closed," smirks and says, "Go home and eat there." I never had a chance to taste the food but I found his attitude toward me as rude and insensitive regardless if they were closed or not. I'm sure the servers are nicer than the owner but he left me with a bad taste. This was my first time and likely my last.
author: Francisco F.

description:
Naysayers gonna naysay but what they say is cray-cray, okay?
Seriously, this is the bombshits if you want fast, friendly delicious Chinese food. 
Is it the super authentic? Prolly not. You want that you go to China Town or over to the Sunset. This is the comfort food that soothes hangovers and flus like nobodies business. I've had most of the menu and it is delicious. The staff is friendly and on point. I have literally never had a bad experience with this joint in two years.
If you're looking for a taste sensation that will redefine your world view, go somewhere else: if you want what you want when you want it, come to Gourmet Carousel.
author: James R.

description:
Imagine a beautifully roasted duck, glistening, crispy skin just sitting there waiting to be sliced. Now imagine someone with a big 'ol cleaver just goes to town on dear Daffy and that's what we were delivered. Big, small, torn up pieces of meat covered bones and bits, not nicely carved breast and leg. I'll admit that I'm a picky eater when it comes to having bones in my meat. I used to be a vegetarian and even though I eat meat regularly now, having to pick meat around bone, marrow, and cartilage sometimes makes my stomach turn. Subsequently, this meal was inedible for me. Even my carnivore husband couldn't get through it before declaring it was rubbish. 

I don't know about the other 100 meals they have on their menu, but I'm certainly not going to try them. I can safely say, avoid the duck.
author: Erin O.

description: Stopped by here for a pre-performance dinner. Was very impressed; the portions were very generous, which made it an excellent deal for the money. Even though it was a Saturday night, we were seated very quickly. People at the table ordered the chicken and shrimp, and everyone enjoyed their meal. If I were in the area again, I would go back.
author: A G.

description: First Gourmet Carousel meal in many years. I boycotted them because they are so rude. Got take-out so I didn't have to spend much time there. Food was average at best, but in checking Yelp I found their health safety rating is dangerous. Check it out at https://www.yelp.com/inspections/gourmet-carousel-san-francisco ......I believe that is at or near the bottom 5% of all restaurants in SF. I won't be going back!
author: Bernard O.

description:
The portion sizes are large. The food is mediocre at best. I live right by here and have been twice. The first time it was ok. The second time, I got mongolian beef, and the cut/quality of meat was so bad that I literally could not eat it. This never happens to me. In fact, I've lived in mainland China and been to some 3rd world parts, and I still ate what I could.

With so many choices for Chinese around, I would avoid this place personally.
author: Neal F.

description:
OMG! This place is horrible - dirty and the food is a joke. Even the service was RUDE! My lunch date asked for a "side" of broccoli and the server yelled at her "NO! You can't do that!!!" All our food for 4 people came out in less than 2 minutes. How is that possible? It seems like the food was already made and then reheated. The rice serving is so big that the stir fry is a side....I thought the rice is a side? 
My salt and pepper rock cod was horrible - greasy and hardly any fish. All greasy batter. I will never go here again.
author: Jennifer S.

description: When the food is good, it's really good, but when the food is bad it's pretty bad too. I really really like your deluxe won ton soup, it tastes almost exactly like the won tons I grew up eating in Taiwan! Their walnut prawns are great and so are there noodle dishes. In the same order, we also ordered the oyster and pork belly clay pot...both my boyfriend and I found cracked oyster shells in the dish and it tasted like we were eating sand when we were chewing on the oysters. Overall, I would still say this is a pretty legit chinese place to eat.
author: Nina H.

description: I've been coming here for YEARS with friends and family. They serve the freshest and best Chinese food with no MSG. I've been scouring all the Chinatown locations in SF for Char Siu (chinese BBQ pork) for that particular flavor and texture as I recalled from the original shop on Grant near Broadway Streets from my childhood. Search no more! They make their Char Siu daily. It's more expensive because you're paying for "al la carte" but well worth it! I usually pick up a couple of orders when I'm in the city. If it makes it home for the drive, I'll freeze the remainder. They also have the best Won Ton Soups. My fave... GaiLan with ginger and LapChung (sp?) I can go on and on.... you'll just have to try them.
author: AnaMaria B.

description: I have been eating here since 1990, maybe earlier? I recall the suits. Much of the staff remain from that time. It is the quintessential hole in the wall Chinese food place... Only that it's in Pacific Heights. Unpretentious comfort food. They always seem to genuinely care about how you are doing.  When I eat there, I always give a snicker at a face I ate near 20 yrs ago. It's place you go to with a friend when you are done with fancy pansy and are testing their "real" meter. The wontons are freshly handmade and the salt & pepper spare ribs are still... Well, yummy fried salt and pepper spare ribs. Actually, Its my naughty... "salt & pepper anything" is good place. The over rice menu still exists with under $10 outta-the-door prices. Keep in mind, the prices are so low, you can order a la carte for  two and still get out under $25. My fav w/a friend was always the crab (seasonal) shared with Wor Won Ton (deluxe) soup. My over rice fav is the prawns & tender greens (I order it with mushrooms). Men always love the Beef Steak Cubes. If you are confused, order the 2-person or family meal. This place also saved my life dozens of times as I had to feed my college sweetheart. One tip: if u get a soup spoon that tastes like bleach, be nice, just ask for a spoon. This place is as " Old School San Francisco " as it gets.
author: Evelyn K.

description: If you want good authentic Chinese food, this is not the place. They use over cooked white meat (chicken) on two of our dishes.
author: Nancy Y.

description: Cheap Food! Food is....just food. I can compare their attitude and service to the Soup Nazi on Seinfeld. Horrible! It's like they don't even want to sell you food! Stupid business!
author: Islam N.

description:
I mean, if you want good chinese food I wouldn't really recommend this place.  However, if you are nearby and want inexpensive and filling food, then come here.  I have gotten their pot stickers twice to go, enjoyed their "green onion pancake" or whatever that thing is, but I find their dishes that essentially highlight the meat to be lacking.  Although if you feel like you want greasy chinese, do it.  There are always moments when that's just what you need.  I'll probably eat it again someday for the sheer reason that it is just down my street.  

Bottom line: cheap and filling
author: Carolyn N.

description: A table full of yummy food and your pockets won't be hurting! This place been here forever! Large portions that isn't expensive around the area. Parking sucks, so when I circle around twice and don't find parking, I'll order to go! ;)
author: S M.

description:
Every one seems to agree on one thing on dining at Gourmet Carousel, and that is Cheap and Filling Chinese food, I will have to agree. 

I stumbled upon this place one night when I was hoping to bring my salt intake for the day to it's maximum potential. Luckily I found GC. Many have stated that the food comes out to quick (which leads people to imagine food  just sitting in the kitchen waiting to be re-heated), but I personally love how quick your food comes out. In addition I find the servers very nice (they might be a little robotic as another yelper put it) but you are there on one sole mission to eat fast cheap filling Chinese food, who cares about the waiter?

I've been here twice which I think is a good testament to the place being an A OK chinese food fix .....while on a budget.
author: Lannette G.

description:
grabbed a quick bite in the new hood after a long day's packing and unpacking.

it's alright.  mostly it's pretty cheap.

we got 
-fried wontons (i'm a sucker for anything i can dip in sweet and sour)
-salted fish fried rice (a little bland, but decent.  palatable for the salted fish fried rice novice)
-salt and pepper beef spareribs (lightly fried, these were as tough as leather, reminded me of my dog's dehydrated chicken strips.  would not order again.)
-rice (which strangely smelled like moth balls)
-a coke

i'll probably go again because it's convenient.  total bill was around $30 with tip.  service was friendly and brisk.  place is clean.

tip:  they give you a free soup to start which is mostly veggies in a broth.  it's a nice freebie for a cold night and when you just want something warm for your tummy without ordering a giant bowl.
author: Josie M.

description:
Yes this place might not be the BEST looking place or prettiest looking place but its my kind of Chinese Restaurant. FAST, CHEAP, and actually good tasting. My co-worker introduced me to this place and I've been going almost on a weekly basis when i want fast and cheap food. 

Their sweet and sour pork lunch special for $4.95! COME ON! does it get better then that? You'd be surprised that not a lot of Chinese Restaurants make sweet and sour pork that great, but this place despite being ONLY $4.95 makes it pretty good! 

I also really like their beef chow fun with gravy (add $1) and without gravy ($5.25, how do you beat that!). It doesn't taste burnt like most places. 

I highly recommend this place if you are near by. If you call in, your food is ready in 5 mins. If you sit down and eat, you order, pour your tea, and next thing you know your food is right in front of you :) and I LOVEE their prices!
author: Annie L.

description: Well my friend lives in this location we were walking down and saw this place I went couple blocks down to buy some tacos and my friend orders a good amount of food here for $30.00, well what I can say is that I tried some of this food and it seems to me this food been siting outside for a while before they reheat it. The chow main taste very good tho,, but the chicken seems like they reheated it and was very chewy.
author: Anthony G.

description:
My co-workers order from here just about every week so I decided to give it a try.

Hot & Sour Soup is very good and enough to feed about 3 people!!!

I ordered  the Mongolian Beef Over rice and it was saltier than I would have liked it because they give you too much sauce (even with the large portion of rice). It tasted fine and there was nothing too amazing about it. 

I will order from Gourmet again but I might try another entree (with the hot and sour soup of course!!!)

Prices are fairly cheap. (like everywhere else in SF)
author: Elisha Y.

description: Kung Poa Chicken was dry and seemed reheated from the day before. Surprisingly bad. The cookie was good. Maybe try a different dish that's fried. Friendly people. I wanted to like it but yikes it's bad.
author: Heather W.

description: Great Food and I can not complain about the prices. Fast and Friendly ready to go.
author: Alex S.

description: I live in Lower Pacific Heights and this is my go-to local restaurant for good Chinese food.  If you are looking for "fancy" place like R&G Lounge or Koi Palace, this isn't the place.  But if you want good, fast, reasonably priced Chinese food that will fill you up, then Gourmet fits the bill.  Favorite dishes include Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings, Pea Sprouts with Garlic Sauce and Eggplant with Pork clay pot.
author: Al M.

description:
Looking for excellent Chinese food at rock bottom prices? Look no further than Gourmet Carousel. Located in Lower Pacific Heights, Gourmet Carousel has been serving up delicious Chinese food for over 25 years. This restaurant epitomizes the saying "don't judge a book by it's cover." The building is in desperate need of a new coat of paint and the dining room needs a complete make-over, but the food is tasty. The tables are a little too close, but that closeness lends to the authentic family feel of the restaurant. 

The food at the restaurant is some of the best in San Francisco. A perk of eating in is the complementary "house soup" for the table. The last time I went it was a scrumptious potato and cabbage soup. Each dish is full of flavor and comes out fast. The menu is packed with house specialties like Sizzling Chicken in a Clay Pot, Shredded Pork in Plum Sauce, Salt and Pepper Spareribs, and Prawns with Hot Sauce. My favorite appetizers are the Fried Egg Rolls, Fried Won Tons, Pot Stickers, Hot and Sour Soup, and Won Ton Soup. Some of the main dish highlights are the Mu-Shu Chicken, Salt and Pepper Prawns, General Tso's Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and any of the fresh vegetable side dishes.

Gourmet Carousel is the best deal in town. Lunch specials start at $4.95 and don't top $5.95. Side dishes average $8 and are so large that my fiance couldn't even finish his Mongolian Beef by himself (that is a first ever).  The only downfall is that they don't deliver. (Gasp!) The Gourmet Carousel moves to it's own beat, but it's a tasty beat. Next time you are looking for a delicious, cheap, Chinese food experience try the Gourmet Carousel.
author: Alice S.

description:
I pass by this place all the time on my way back from Whole Foods.  The name of the restaurant is a real misnomer.  The chow mein was dry, and their green onion pancakes were typical, thin-style--the kind you can't finish, not because it's hearty and filling, but because it isn't very good to begin with.

It's unfortunate that Gourmet Carousel is a let-down, because Chinese in this area are few and far between.  The few blocks down to Polk are worth it for better food.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I'm a fan of this place because: 
a) it's 2 blocks from my apt
b) it's cheap 
c) the portions are massive 
d) they have good fried shrimp

...the answer is e) all of the above. A few friends and I hit Gourmet Carousel to celebrate Chinese New Year. We decided to splurge and go with the preset Peking Dinner option for 3 people which is $12/person. It comes with Hot and Sour Soup, Fried Shrimp, Kung Pao Chicken, Monglian Beef, Pork Fried Rice, and Sweet & Sour Spareribs. Hah, if by 3 people they meant dinner for 8 people, then yes this was enough food. The three of us stuffed ourselves silly and we hardly made a dent. The to-go boxes we left the restaurant with seriously weighed like 10 lbs. Looks likeI will be eating chinese leftovers for the rest of week.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Wife drove to Oakland to pick me up from Oakland Airport. On our way back, she consoled me and expressed a brokenhearted understanding on my Warriors not making the playoff. And after a two hour flight, we decided to grab a quick dinner together. 

My tiring evening must be short, because I needed to be in the South Bay the following morning. So we landed at this filthy cornered Chinese Restaurant for din-din, which is not too far from our crib. 

We know parking is very troublesome in the area, but we managed to park our van on Pine St. Seated immediately, we ordered a couple of items. We ordered the Steamed-Chicken and Steamed Gai-lan (Chinese Broccoli) with Oyster-Sauce. The $10.00 sliced Steamed-chicken was very tender and complimented very well with the special sauce on the side. The $6.00 veggie side was very crunchy and tasted well with/without the Oyster-Sauce. Also, rice was served with the meal. 

Despite a low-rating from yelpers who reviewed this restaurant, the food and service was ok. I know, we could've got a better meal in Chinatown, but we had to try somewhere else.
author: Matt G.

description:
I don't think I've ever seen it on another menu. But in any case I'll be going back to G.C. for their Three Shredded Meat Chow Fun w./ Egg (Triple Threat!). Most places over cook/ burn their chow fun, but theirs was perfectly cooked and loaded for meat lovers. 

With the full table of food our bill barely reached over 60 bucks for 6 people and we had left overs for days.   

We received friendly attentive service, so I will be coming back outside of my trips to Clement Street and Chinatown.
author: Dennis S.

description: My husband and I have eaten at this restaurant for 15 to 20 yrs....no more!   The bok choy was black on the stem and when we reported it and left all the food,the waiter and owner laughed at us.fs
author: Frances S.

description:
Went here after work with coworkers from So Cal. Ordered the Special Dinner for 6 for $59+. 

We had: Melon Soup, Beef w/ Bok Choy, Fried Sand Dab, Salt & Pepper Shrimp, Steamed Oysters, Peking Spareribs, Fried chicken, Winter Melon Squash Mix, and of course, Rice. Red Bean soup for dessert. Fortune Cookies with Oranges accompanies the bill.  

Everything was very good, though bordering on salty, msg, and greasy. Service was fast and friendly. There was so much food, we even had leftovers. 

This place was known for its Bacon with Pickled veges (Mui Choy Kow Yook), a really delicious, juicy, salty, fat, oily pork dish. Not recommended for those with high cholesterol. Great for college kids.

A good place for a quick dinner when you can't think of another place. You'll likely have to circle the block a couple of times to get a good parking space but don't let that deter you. Parking isn't as bad as on Irving or Clement St. 

We'll be coming back soon...
author: Hagow C.

description: This place is great!   introduced by my business partner to me who has come here for years.........the owner (father) and daughter came over to give us a smile, talked a bit and the food as well as the service was really good!  I would highly recommend Gourmet Carousel if you want quality food and service.
author: Rob F.

description:
My family used to go here quite often when we were little.  We stopped going because it was too far and parking is a pain.

Anyway, last year, I was at a seminar near Holiday Inn so for lunch I popped in here.  I ordered some type of chow mein.  Worse I've ever eaten.  Very greasy and loaded w/ MSG.  I was thirsty for the rest of the day! :(

This place may be cheap but the food is bad.  How they manage to stay in business for so long is a mystery!
author: Wendy H.

description: Whenever I am in SF to visit the grandparents this is always our go to place that is always super satisfying.  This is down home Chinese AWESOMENESS.  We always order from their "wa choy" menu, and all of it is delicious!  Whether we order the 4 person menu or one of their large 10 person banquet menu, we always leave this place with a smile in our bellies  =)
author: NéeNée L.

description: Food was pretty average for a Chinese restaurant, I've had their lunch special before which is to DiE for!!!  But on this visit we stopped in for dinner and
author: Mimi W.

description:
This placeis great! Ive passed by this place for years before i decided to try it today,i ordered the cashew chicken chow mein, i wasn't expecting much, but when the plate came it was a big portion.
I couldn't believe my eyes all this food, i thought i couldn't finish it but i did.
The workers are all nice, they refill your teas or water without asking.
This place makes panda express look silly, i would rather eat here everyday if i could.
author: Corey W.

description:
I have not seen $4.95 lunch dishes since the last century. I wish I had yelped this place earlier. In terms of their food and price and location, I absolutely could have been coming in here instead of Ah Lin and the Wok Shop. I love both of those places, but I give Gourmet Carousel 5 stars for overall experience.

They offer lots of rice for their plate dishes. No soup, but for this price, I don't think they could have survived. I had the duck over Chinese greens and the duck's skin was super crispy. They don't offer water immediately. I didn't need it; I was happy with the tea. (Also, my duck dish was slightly more than the $4.95 that most of the other dishes were.)

This place had Asians eating here, and not just Americanized Asians. That's always a good sign to me.
author: Ruiqiu K.

description:
Massive servings of great food at tiny prices.  That equals five stars in my universe any time.  Complaining about poor atmosphere, dirt, crowding etc. under these circumstances is ridiculous. Big, yummy, cheap are much more important than all of those other factors.  Besides, anyone who has been outside the luxury hotels in Asia will find an endless arrray of tacky, dirty, crowded restaurants, and most of them are wonderful. Get over it, the world is a tacky, dirty, crowded place. Like Gourmet Carousel. Where the food is GREAT!

My favorite dish at GC: fried oysters. Huge, crispy, juicy chunks of fried heaven.
author: Robert C.

description:
Dirty. Ok this is a typical cheap Chinese restaurant. Actually surprisingly cheap considering the location. It's cheaper than Chinese restaurants near busy college campuses. 

Anyways I was avoiding Chinese establishments for awhile bc I hate how so many are just plain dirty. Patrons who frequent these places are used to it and wipe down their utensils with hot tea. Sorry but why can't my stuff be clean to begin with?

I just ate here but shouldn't have. There was a hair in my food and I don't like how the waitress filled my water cup. Like don't touch the rim where my mouth goes. Luckily I had bottled water in my purse. 

I may be picky or irritated at this point. But Chinese food tastes good and has lots of veggies (which I need) but why can't I find decent one
author: Leena C.

description: I've eaten here so many times, and will again tomorrow, so it's time for a review.  First of all, you do not come here for the ambiance, you come for the good food.  It's down home Chinese cooking at a great price.  The food arrives quickly, piping hot and delicious.  Get past the rustic interior, and enjoy some authentic home style cooking.  The staff is friendly and efficient.  I recommend anything in a clay pot, the crispy skin or steamed chicken, and their Westlake Soup.  The high quality food and low prices will not disappoint.
author: Lesli L.

description:
this place has been here forever.
and the decor has never changed.
i had the classic hung tao yee wonton soup with fake crab.
it was only barely passable. lots of pork gristle in the wonton and i learned that i really don't like surimi (fake crab) that much and there was a ton of it in the soup. two things were missing in this dish - minced cilantro and bbq pork bits. i guess i am better off with the basics like noodles and rice dishes here.
author: Jeff W.

description: I stopped going here when they refused to give me a check listing what we had in English.  They charged us and it was more than I thought it should have been but wouldn't give us a check listing what we ordered, just a total and they wouldn't discuss it either.  In order not to embarrass everyone I paid but I've never been back.
author: BellaLissa B.

description:
Cheap and the food taste great I would eat here everyday of the week if it wasn't so far from me

Good luck in the parking because its difficult. It's a small price to pay if your going to try out there delicious ribs mmmmmm...

Maybe ill see you there;)
author: Michael m.

description:
Only been here for take-out, just so you know.

I love their food--so cheap and so good, and hearty portions!  Not too greasy either.
author: Fannie S.

description:
My relatives have been coming out here from the Richmond district for years for lunch take outs and having dinner banquets here because of their large portions and cheap prices.  The food is far from gourmet, and while I've had better Chinese food, some of their dishes are fairly tasty!  

This weekend, we had a birthday banquet for ten for my aunt's birthday.  You know what that means, eight courses...just when I thought all the glutinous eating was going to be over along with the holidays! Since it was a banquet menu, everything was ordered ahead of time, so sorry, that I don't know the proper names for everything!

*Scallop soup (has some chicken in it too)--good for the seafood lovers.
*Minced squab or chicken (it varies by restaurant) w/lettuce cups--okay, I thought it tasted slightly off, but my aunt says it was just me.  
*Peking duck with buns--missing the green onion slivers, but it was crispy, meaty & didn't have tons of fat & the buns were so hot!
*Some kind of fish--didn't eat because I don't like fish.  Waitress filleted it in less than a minute, gotta love that about Chinese restaurants.
*Crispy skinned chicken with shrimp chips--loved it..moist and crispy skinned (of course), the shrimp chips were crispy (sometimes they're soggy) & they weren't really greasy.
*Shrimp with shells & eyes in tact---didn't eat because I didn't want to get my hands totally messy...& shrimp in the shells with the eyes totally freak me out!
*Black mushrooms and cabbage--Ate some of the cabbage, but not the mushrooms because I don't like black mushrooms.
*Beef with bok choy--The beef was pretty tender and the sauce was good and not overly salty.
*Braised yee fu noodles--"The Birthday Noodles."  Came with plenty of veggies and was nice and light.  

All of this came with the standard cut orange slices (so sweet) and fortune cookies.  The wait staff was very attentive to our party and even poured the wine that we had brought and gave us paper plates for the cake we brought.  

I always get worried if I don't see any Chinese people in a Chinese restaurant, don't worry it was about half the restaurant, so this is no Panda Express like restaurant!  I only continue to come to Gourmet Carousel for my family's banquet dinners, but if you're around the neighborhood and want some Chinese food, check it out..and walk or bus it, because parking can be difficult!
author: Cat C.

description:
I always liked this place a lot... maybe too much, according to some of the other reviews I've read.

Because for me, it boils down to two dishes: barbecued pork wonton and shrimp roasted with salt and pepper.

the wonton soup has always been delicious to me. Bok choy and big strips of pork floating about. Flavorful! It actually tastes like something to me, whereas some wonton soups I've had have broth that tastes like dishwater.

but seriously, the prawns. No one else has written about them. I LOVE these little filter feeders. They're roasted in salt with shells on and served with raw jalapenos sprinkled about and some cilantro. So crunchy you can eat the shells. Salty! Delicious. Really... try them if the ambiance here is not too gross for you.
author: Liza T.

description:
fast & cheap, but that's it.

we got takeout: tomato beef skinny noodles (jin mien), beef w/ black beans chow fun, & mixed veggies.  everything was drowning in grease.  like, even for a chinese restaurant, it's a stomach churning level of oily.  the beef was also sketchy tasting & chewy in a gross way.  

at this point, i don't even care whether it's authentic chinese or not.  but just simply as food, it's disgusting.  not coming back.
author: Miss K.

description:
Coming to Gourmet Carousel with a group and being able to try everything helped me determine that there's nothing to write home about this place. 

There were a couple of dishes that were OK, a bunch that were subpar, and a couple that were almost inedible. For being so greasy and salty you would think that there would be more flavor? Nope. The fish covered in some kind of sweet and sour sauce was particularly terrible because it didn't even taste halfway fresh.

It wasn't too expensive though, so it's a solid two stars. Even though it's down the street from me I have never since elected to eat here.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Cheap, Fast, good size portions.

Chicken with black bean sauce stirred fried flat noodles
chicken with string beans and rice.
Scallion Pie - Not the usual ones that I am use to eating. 

Both plates were $5.50/each.
author: Jboogie L.

description: A lot of food for an inexpensive price. Salt & Pepper spareribs, shrimp and scramble eggs, beef chow fun are some of the favorites. The mongolian beef here is different. Service is good but if it gets busy it does suffer.
author: Collin L.

description:
Dinner for three with soup, three dishes, rice, and wine for just over $40? And the food is good and not too Americanized? This is my kind of place.

The most recent time I went here we had the peppered spare ribs, walnut shrimp, and broccoli with roast duck, as well as hot and sour soup. Everything was fabulous, plus there was enough that there was a little leftover. I left feeling full to bursting -- and very happy.
author: Unity K.

description:
Gourmet Carousel can be good, or it can be pretty bad.  It all depends on what you get.  I like their eggplant in garlic sauce and string bean dishes.  Their braised tofu is pretty good too.  Although I'm not usually a fan of sweet and sour chicken, it's pretty tasty here, as well as the sesame chicken.  They give you a lot of food for a good price.

Some of their dishes can be pretty bland though, like the Singapore rice noodles or the snow peas.
author: Karen W.

description:
Hadn't been here in years, but it was close to where my friend lived, and it turned out that he didn't have as much time for lunch, as I had originally anticipated.  I threw out having fried oysters down on Polk, but there is typically a tong wait.  After getting change to feed the extra hungry parking meters ($2.00/hour), I perused the menu.  Won ton soup, definitely, as I am still recovering from my stomach ailment.  Then how about a couple of entrees, which we could split; sounded like a varied lunch.  Then my friend suggest a green onion pancake, so we decided that one entree would be enough.  The bowl of won ton soup was enough to feed a table of four with a cup full each; yummy.  The green onion pancake was a large, dinner place size, served with a peanut sauce; again enough for four to share, as an appetizer.  The final course was green bean and beef, served over rice.  Hot tea comes with the meal.  Half of this last entree remained, but as both of us had full afternoons, we declined to take it home.  The best part was the price; before tip, the total was $15.
Will definitely go back, and suggest that if you are in the neighborhood, that you give it a shot.  You will not be disappointed!!
author: Bill E.

description: Ordered Peking Duck--full order 12 buns. $26.  I got five legs, no breasts, the rest  chopped up parts with bone and gristle that were obviously the remainders of other dishes rather than the pieces of a single duck.
author: Robert M.

description:
I recently moved to Long Beach and boy has it been hard to find a chinese restaurant that comes even close to Gourmet!!

I definitely have some childhood sentiment when thinking/writing about this place but the fact is that the food is delicious, prices are low, and portions are plentiful. 

I have read some of the other reviews and have to say... if you are looking for good/attentive service, you should not be frequenting chinese restaurants... anyone agree with me??? 

By chinese restaurant standards, Gourmet Carousel is clean and the food definitely hits the spot. My suggestions are trying the Mongolian Beef, Bean Sprouts in Garlic Sauce (not on the menu), or the Seafood Wonton Soup. 

There are 100's of chinese restaurants in San Francisco and overall I think San Franciscans are spoiled with the selection compared to other cities... Trust me, I have lived in NYC and LA.

Overall I have to say that as someone who grew up in the city and has tried plenty of different chinese restaurants, this one is definitely a top choice especially when you take into consideration the price, the location (lower pacific heights), and the taste!!!

Cheers!
author: Matt G.

description:
Up until I was age 12, my family would come here religiously. This was the go-to place, pretty much our house of worship. I don't know why we came here so often. Thinking back, the food was okay, the prices were okay. I guess we just felt comfortable because we were familiar with the staff and they were nice to us because we were regulars. Anyway you can definitely find better Chinese food in The City. I haven't been here in over 10 years so I don't know how it's like nowadays.

Update: We went back here recently and the food is absolutely disgusting. Everything is drenched in the same sauce. Ugh.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I haven't seen the soup nazi old lady in a while... I hope she's okay!  The rest of the staff is still there.  

I usually get the takeout, which is fast and efficient.  These folks get grumpy and *shut you down* if you call past like 9:15 for takeout, though.  

The soups are still their strength. Didn't like their kungpao chicken at all... Tai Chi's and especially Andy's are way better.
author: Dave N.

description: This should be 1.5 stars, but I rounded up. That's just the kind of person I am. The food is cheap; true.  The food is good; false.  I received a huge piping hot portion of chow fun from the pleasant server. I also like that they bring a whole pot of tea.  I drink a lot of tea. However, the food was literally dripping in grease from cooking in way too much oil.  I asked for a box for leftovers, but when I placed the food in the box and got a look at that pool of oil left on the plate I threw the remaining food away. Surprisingly, it took more than an hour for the stomach cramps from all that oil to kick in. I didn't expect to make it back to the office. So I guess not getting the runs within 15 minutes deserves at least one star....right?
author: Eve C.

description:
Cheap, cheap chinese food...

This a major cops hang out.......Why?

Plates are huge, prices are small...
author: Raider J.

description:
Unfortunately the closest food source to my condo.

Fortunately I don't eat Chinese food.

Unfortunately my boyfriend elects to bring home Gourmet Carousel when it's his "dinner night."

Greasy and bland.  So greasy in fact that you are practically drinking oily MSG.  Yuck.  

Yelp couldn't say it better : methinks not
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
Positives:
Cheap food that is served up fast and they give you loads of it.

Negatives:
Laden with MSG.  Hot and sour soup had non-disclosed shrimp (these things make me sick to my stomach).  Greasy.  

While I was eating, I thought the food was okay, but then 3 am came around and I ended up in the bathroom for an hour.

I'll spare you the details, but let's just say that it's not very pleasant.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
Why haven't I reviewed GC before? Forgot, I guess. 
I've been going here for years, but not often enough, and not recently.
I guess I always go with exactly 9 people and get a banquet-table and really pig out.  Do any of you other bok-goi's notice that Chinese people almost always eat out with a crowd?

Start with the negative: It's a creepy-awful room.  Who needs windows?  Wood paneling.  Bad lighting.  Picture the spawn of a basement rec-room and a dentist office waiting room.  OK...it's darker than most of those flourescent-and-formica places, which is a good thing, but the place just feels claustrophobic.

So the other night I had 10 friends and neighbors down at my house. I said "Chinese Banquet!" but a couple people didn't want to go out, so I ordered take out (they don't deliver, unfortunately).  Also, there were a couple "vegetarians" who eat seafood. (RANT) What's up with that?  Are chickens smarter than salmon?  Do fish feel no pain?  Can you hear me screaming if I'm underwater? (/ RANT)

So we got a boatload of GOOD food for $107. Divide by 11 and you'll still be under the magic number of $10/person.  And we had Peking duck, garlic-scallion crab, abalone, a clay pot dish, Snow pea sprouts with garlic, seafood chow fun, and about 5 other things, and we had leftovers.  Dungeness crab for dinner tonight!
The killer is that everything was really good. OK, the salt 'n pepper squid suffered a bit from the 15 minute drive home, but we ate really well, especially considering the pittance we spent.  My friends and neighbors all raved!   
And were were completely free of anything resembling cashew chicken, Mongolian lamb, or sweet and sour pork.  

How to eat well:
1. Call 9 friends 
2. go to Gourmet Carousel
3. order extravagantly
4. eat like a king
5. split the bill
6. Start thinking of another 9 friends to impress with your ordering prowess.
author: Rob B.

description: I grew up eating at this restaurant since it was only a block from my house. I have to say for the value, this place is great! It is super reasonably priced and the food is pretty good. If you're expecting five star service and gourmet food, then don't go here. However if you want good food for a cheap price, then this is the place!
author: Katrina L.

description:
I have been to the Carousel twice, once this week and once on Christmas Day. Both times, there were pluses and minuses about the place.

Pluses:
-The food is cheap and plentiful. The last time I went, I ordered the vegetable chow mein. Nice thick noodles and loads of veggies, plus a huge helping of rice and a soda cost me $10 with tip. My omnivore friends ordered five meals that they shared family style. They left with two orders worth of leftovers, each paying around $15. 
-The location is on the border of the Tenderloin, which leads to some entertaining sites on the way in. However, you should put all your valuables in the trunk of your car if you park on the street. 
-Big screen television let us watch the Giants versus the A's while we ate. 

Minuses:
-There isn't much vegetarian stuff and they throw tofu into random meat dishes so it takes a while for me to find a meal
-The people never smile and always look like they are working 18 hour days
-It borders the Tenderloin

I don't hate going here, but it would never be my first choice for good Chinese
author: Jake W.

description:
I come here way too much. Waaaay too much. It doesn't help that I live nearby and can run out in my pajamas.

Thumbs up: chinese broccoli beef, yang chow fried rice, pot stickers, foil-wrapped chicken

Thumbs down: kung pao shrimp, every kind of soup
author: Jenny T.

description:
Food mostly good & Inexpensive for the portions you get. 
Best KOW YUKE (Chinese pork belly) that i know of.
Good CLAMS IN BLACK BEAN SAUCE; would be perfect with a little less salt.
Love the simple soup they bring to your table to start--
     clear tasty broth with a vegetable.
Easy to get to but parking can be difficult because of their location on Pine St.
author: Vera P.

description:
Chinese? Siamese? Japanese? Lebonese? Whatever it is, it's good!

I've been here several times in the past. The first time I came to Carousel, I didn't have such a good experience. I had a plate filled with what looked like live prawns. I remember peeling the eyes out with my fork and watched it fly into some someone's drink. haha :D

Yeah, I never ordered that stuff again, but every other experience was great.

The prices are very reasonable and the food is beyond average.

Yesterday I had Prawns Curry w/ Fried Rice and a friend took over a plate of Potstickers which I can't eat! But sure does smell good. The reason I wrote this review is because I still have that steamy scent in my nose. Mmmm. . . And yes I took a shower!

If you do decide to visit this multi selection food palace, try these

Prawns Curry
Shrimp Fried Rice (not ordinary, good stuff)
Mongolian Beef (as recommended by a friend)
Potstickers (as recommended by a friend)
and 7up, it goes great w/ everything.  

Definitely recommended to you my friends.

Seriously though, Can someone tell me the food specialty of this restaurant.
author: Sani S.

description:
First try calling... ring ring ring. No answer. 
Second time... "GOHMAAAAYYY!" 
"Um hi, would it be possible to get a reservation for 4 people tonight?" 
"TWELF?"
"No. Four."
"TWO???"
"NO! FOUR! 1-2-3-4!!!"
"FAW??"
"YES. FOUR!"
"Oh. Firs come, firs serve"
Agh. "Ok...."

How do people order take out here? Seriously. Its been such a struggle on the phone that I will walk the two blocks and just eat there, which I have done several times now because I simply don't have the patience to place the take-out order over the phone. Ironic. 

Overall, the food here is not bad, but its pretty hit or miss depending on what you order. Spicy beef cubes with tender greens, spicy eggplant, pork stuffed tofu, westlake soup. Good. Egg foo yung, scallion pancakes, seafood claypot. Terrible. The catfish in black bean sauce is just too oily and has too many bones. I've ordered a couple other dishes too, but nothing is that memorable. Overall, its decent, convenient, and it got my pau-pau's stamp of approval.  It's my go-to Chinese place in the hood. Just not for take-out...
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Special dinner for four at $28!  Have to add rice, tea, tax, and tip, so the total was still less than $40.

The crispy half chicken was moist and flavorful.  The Mandarin pork chops were okay but a bit tough.  The tofu stuffed with fish was yummy.  The beef with bok choy was tender and had plenty of both meat and vegetables.
author: Coyote B.

description:
Stopped in to eat there because it was close to my son's home at the time. Didn't expect it to be chinese food, although of course that was clear from the sign once we were there. Is "Gourmet Carousel" a Chinese phrase?

Nevertheless, food is inexpensive and good. Maybe not gourmet quality. Gary Chu's in Santa Rosa is gourmet quality and the differences are clear. But I would happily go back.
author: Matt H.

description:
I've been coming to Gourmet Carousel for as long as I can remember, even before the fire and when their name used to be Gourmet Kitchen!  (Now, who can remember that?!)  I've seen the owner's children grow up right before my eyes as they used to hang out by the register, then man the register, and now they are not there anymore.  I've seen the same waiters and waitresses and they recognize our family too.

We usually stick to our favorites when we come, and we do have a lot of them.  On my last visit with my family, this is what we ordered:

* Mustard Greens with Calamari - one of my favorites!  Tentacles and pickled radishes compliment this dish!
* Roast Prawns with Salt and Pepper - deep fried with a nice taste!  Eat up the shell and head too!
* Salt and Pepper Pork Chops - deep fried and full of flavor!  Definitely eat with rice!
* Black Bean Sauce Clams - we always get this, and there lots of onions and bell peppers in there too.
* Pan Fried Whole Flounder - a little on the small end this time, but usually you get a decent size fish.
* Mixed Seafood and Vegetables in Bird's Nest - I have always loved the bird's nest, potato strings deep fried into a bird nest shape and loaded with veggies and seafood.  Apparently, my four year old nephew loves the bird's nest too now!
* Salted Fish Fried Rice - I'm not a big fan of fried rice myself, but my family loves the stuff.  They always order it here.
* Bitter Melon and Chicken Chow Fun, wet style - I'm not a big fan of the bitter melon, but it's you can still eat the chow fun since the taste of the bitter melon didn't get into everything.

Notable mentions that we didn't get this time, but have in the past:
* Fatty Pork Meat with Pickled Veggies - oh so good, and oh so fatty!
* Deep Fried Bean Cake  - I like mine with lots of gravy!
* Stir Fried Veggies, whatever is in season - simple stir fry with garlic and it's yummy!
