We always start our meals with soup here - whether it's house soup or what.  It's simple, refreshing and I like it.  And you always get fresh oranges and fortune cookies here too.  Believe it or not, I actually really like their fortune cookies here and I've gotten some exception fortunes out of them too!

Overall, Gourmet Carousel will always be a steady repeat for my family and I.  Yes, over the years service can be good and bad.  But all in all, good Chinese food for a good price can't be beat.  And it's a telling sign when you've been in business for at least sixteen years.
author: Teri C.

description:
This place is FAST! Usain BOLT Fast!

Came here for lunch on Friday and as soon as I put my order in, it was being handed to me. 

They have an extensive lunch special menu with all the regulars. Mongolian beef, sweet and sour pork, etc...

What really makes this place is great is the price. They load you up with a  heap of food for only $6!

I've been trying to find a solid, quick and cheap chinese place in my neck of the woods and I think this one takes the cake. You would never think this place could impress, especially with it's dingy green awning out front and a name that is simply RIDICULOUS. BUT, it was worth a shot and I am fully impressed.
author: Mike K.

description:
The category:
Cheap eats

The seven-word skinny:
Inexpensive, plentiful, Chinese takeout for under five

The review:
It's a (insert adverse SF weather condition here) night and you're starving but don't want to cook or go out to eat.  Worse yet, a cursory glance at the wallet indicates that you have but a single Abraham Lincoln to your name.  Fear not, though, 'cuz Gourmet Carousel will fill your stomach with good food with change for your five bucks to boot!

I've been ordering takeout from "Gouhmay" (as phone regulars have come to know it as) for nearly a year now and in terms of value, it's hard to top.  My personal favorites are the Yang Chow Fried Rice and the Singapore Rice Noodles, both packed to the brim of their 32 oz. takeout boxes.  I've only dined-in once and I ordered the dinner combination special.  Not on par with the aforementioned rice and noodle plates but still great value.

The good:
Price, portions, speed, variety, decent for large groups (I always see at least one party of 6+ on nights), possibly BYOW w/ no corkage fee, good mix of authentic and "Americanized" Chinese dishes

The bad:
ambiance and decor or nothing to write home about

The notable:
mixed clientele representative of diverse menu - there's something for everyone

The Junius pick:
Yang Chow Fried Rice

The person you're dating:
Should not be brought here.

The significant other/spouse:
Should come with you to pick up the order while you're double-parked on Pine.

The last time I was there:
April 2, 2006

The number of times I've been there:
More than 30.
author: Junius H.

description:
I've been going here since I was a BABY. Literally, a teenie tiny cute ass baby. My family and I only go here during dinner time on the weekends with some relatives so we usually get those big tables with the roll-y thing in the middle to roll around the food... like a carousel??!!

Location: It's on the corner of 2 busy streets so parking can be a pain! It's also small inside and the waiting area is pretty much a closet.

Service: Hit or Miss! The old lady at the front, calling out numbers and names seems really mean but what do you expect?? Waiters and waitresses are always nice to us though!

Food: SOOOO GOOD!!! We always order: Ginger Crab, Pork Spareribs, Duck & those rice buns, Black Bean Clams, and some form of vegetable. My sisters have driven from SJ to SF just to order takeout from here! The crab is always seasoned just perfectly, the pork ribs and sweet and sour sauce is soo good with rice ... so is the clams and the sauce!!

But I don't know about the prices... I have yet to pay for the bill :P Usually someone fights over it so we never see it again but I love this place so much because it has sentimental value and the food is pretty damn good!!

If you're expecting an upscale, quiet, and super clean restaurant, avoid this restaurant!!
author: T L.

description:
Gourmet Carousel is a place I always drive by but have never thought to try because the name is terrible!  It's really one of the cleaner Chinese restaurants, quiet with a homey feel.  The food is very good, authentic and so inexpensive!  The servings are huge, perfect for a family style meal.

Special WonTon Soup: enough for 2 as a meal or 5 as a starter.  Flavorful broth with tons of beef and pork.

Peking Duck:  I got a half order, which really was a full order with less steamed buns.  Not only do you get the crispy skin, but they give you a ton of meat too!

Salt and Pepper Prawns & Salt and pepper pork:  These dishes could have used a little more salt and pepper but they were perfectly fried.

Stir Fried green beans with minced pork:  Powerful garlic flavor so bring your mints!  They were a little too greasy for me.

Dinner for four with way too much food and tons of leftovers: $50.00!!!
author: Jeanne C.

description: I've been going to Carousel regularly for nearly 10 years.  Great place for a quick quiet dinner.  Food is very good and prices very reasonable.  This place is usually about 50% tourists and 50% locals and a lot of take out orders.  Service is very good and friendly.
author: Mark L.

description: Two stars for the low prices and the portions of food. Another than that, not really worth it. I've been here a few times, mostly because I was starving and chinese food sounded really good. The meat dishes here make me think about becoming a vegetarian. It just doesn't taste right and has a weird consistency. Just stay clear of any meat and I think you will be fine.
author: Nate C.

description:
Ok the 5 Stars is for the Duck Soup with Won Ton (or is it Won Ton with roast duck?).  Anyways, thats all I ordered and it made me weep. Yeah it was that good!   It is basically  soup with a lot of roast duck and deep fried won ton.  I think that the Fried Won Ton makes the soup.  I have never had Won Ton soup with fried won tons in it so this soup was not only delicious but a very pleasant surprise.  The rest of the food that we ate was okay but I still think about that damn Duck Soup!  

If you are going to order one dish on the menu make it the Duck Won Ton Soup.  And it cost about $6!!  Gotta love it.

Oh yeah, and if you try going there for lunch on a weekday --good luck.
author: tony g.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant. definitely portion-wise you get more here for your money than any non-all-you-can-eat. taste wise- slightly above average, the food is fresh and the place is clean. Whenever I have non-SF friends who are easily culturally overwhelmed, I bring them here, and they love it. I order the basic chicken, pork, beef items some pot stickers and a soup. I don't think this is authentic Chinese. I go to china town, the restaurants are slightly different, I wont really know authentic until I visit China.
author: Steven L.

description: Every restaurant has a niche, and this place is great for people without a palate who want to save money.
author: M L.

description:
Hmmm, what can I say, if I ever need a chinese food fix, I will check out Gourmet Carousel.

Why......
Location - it's just a block away. 
Price - CHEAP
Food - good.
author: jubi l.

description:
Inexpensive Chinese food for Chinese people.

Yes, there is a distinction between Chinese food for the general public and Chinese food for Chinese people.  More specifically, Gourmet Carousel is for Southern (Cantonese) folks.  Their specialty is NOT pot stickers or green onion pancakes.  I think they only carry those items because a lot of people expect all Chinese restaurants to carry them.

I've been eating here pretty regularly for the most part.  One of the only drawback is the difficulties with parking around the neighborhood.

For dinners, stick with their set menus.  There's always a good variety of stuff to satisfy.  Of note, their clams with black bean sauce and their fried chicken are both really good.  Their salt and pepper prawns may take some getting used to for some as they come complete with legs, head and everything in between.

For lunch, I really really really like their dry fried beef chow fun.  It's one of the best ANYWHERE.  Lately, I've also been liking their prawns with scrambled egg over rice.  The eggs are soft scrambled just the way I like them (a bit runny).
author: Winnie C.

description: Value for dollar is fantastic. Had sweet and sour pork, a little tougher meat than other places but high quality nonetheless, so just a matter of preference. Served with tea, rice, and soup was $9 -- could not finish everything. Great atmosphere and service.
author: James C.

description:
I grew up eating at this restaurant and used to think it was great.  Fast forward to today and I realize that it's just ok.  You get good portions, it's inexpensive, and the food is alright, but the staff (who's been there since I was a kid) aren't the friendliest.  Then again, after so many years, I'm used to them.

Get my dad's favorite, which is the clams with black bean sauce.
author: Abby N.

description:
Inexpensive and nothing fancy.

Try the bbq pork wonton soup or the egg fo yung.
author: Misha F.

description:
I went there for dinner with someone who goes there quite a bit so I really didn't need to look at the menu, but I did and noticed how large it was. 

Because I was used to very, very small portions I wanted to also order a chicken dish and my dining companion kind of looked at me a bit strange. But did it anyway. WOW, so much flipping food! I was not used to that.

Also very fast and friendly service, even on a Friday night at 7:30.
If you want a very fancy place to go, this is not the place. But if you just want some good, fast food, then go here. 

We Ordered:
Salt and Pepper Spare Ribs
Beef Steak Cubes
General Tsou (spelling??) Chicken
Pork Fried Rice

All was delicious. But what I would give FIVE STARS to was their soup. Since I don't have access to the menu anymore, I don't remember the name of it. Bean Curd Soup? I am not sure but they use homemade stock and it was awesome!
author: Christine S.

description:
My cousin was visiting SF from Boston and since she was craving good Chinese food we went here.  We have come here before, but I don't remember it :-).  The restaurant was quite busy when we walked in-- definitely a good sign!

We ordered a set menu ("woh choy") which had a variety of dishes: seafood and corn soup, peking duck with steamed buns, salt and pepper quail, ginger and scallion crab, baked chicken with shrimp chips, mushrooms and bok choy, and sweet and sour whole fish.  We added on szechuan tofu and egg foo young for my cousin's boyfriend who is vegetarian.

While the food was tasty, I wouldn't say it was spectacular.  The food took a while and slowly came out one dish at a time.  The soup didn't have a ton of flavor, the buns from the peking duck were sort've pasty, and the crab wasn't really meaty.

If you are in the area, give the restaurant a try, butI probably wouldn't go out of my way in the future.
author: Christopher W.

description:
It's by my house. Tons of good vegetarian dishes. 

Not super exciting - just great takeout.
author: Janet B.

description:
They say you can judge a restaurant by how crowded it may be...here is the restaurant that is just that.This place sits right between Franklin and Pine Street.
Dark green banner it says it all.
Bottom line: The Food is good. not as expensive as other Chinese restaurants here in the city. I always call orders in for takeout. It's not a huge  place so it get crowded around lunch and dinner time.
The place can use a gentle clean up and new carpeting. The staff is courteous. They accept credit cards only if the order is $10 or more only. But thats cool.
Enjoy!
author: Smooth R.

description:
Somehow it feels to me like the quality has decreased here. I remember coming here the first few times and liking it. But recently the dishes have not been tasting so great. 
Another thing: we used to get a bowl of soup with dinner but they just stopped it. You can't get people used to something and then just take it away without explanation... 
We don't go here much anymore but rather go to Ah Lin, around the corner, where the food is really good and the owner is a sweetheart.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
What a great deal for some good traditional Chinese food, although they do have americanized Chinese food too for those less adventurous souls.  Huge portions at bargain basement prices.  The wait staff is super friendly, but the host is a bit brief at times.  I think she owns the place...  whatever as long as the food is delicious and cheap I have nothing to complain about.  I usually go there with a friend and if we each order one item we would typically have leftovers for 2 meals...

two thumbs way up for this place.
author: Steven T.

description:
When my office was in the neighborhood, I used to eat lunch here almost every day. Since I've moved on, I still come back every once in a while when I happen to be in the area.

 What this place offers is large portions of  Chinese food at rock-bottom prices. It is very popular, so the food doesn't just sit around. It always tastes fresh, if occasionally on the greasy side.

My personal favorite dish is the salt and pepper squid, but none of the food is bad. Just come with the appropriate expectations-- this place is neither fancy nor creative. It is reliable, and a good value, however.
author: Walter P.

description:
I have been eating here since they opened in 1980 or so. Believe it or not it was a steak house after the old grocery store closed and when they began to serve Chinese food, they still kept the prime rib on the menu for a long time. I was sad to see the prime rib go, but it's okay, it was a little weird to here my order repeated back to me as PLIME LIBBY?

Back when I went through my vegetarian phase for a couple of years it was my go to place for braised tofu and rice which is the best that I have had anywhere. The chow fun is good, I prefer the shrimp chow fun with $2,00 extra shrimp, but be advised their noodle dishes are great but very oily, so if you hate oil then stay away from them. 

I don't care for the fried rice, it ain't ghetto enough for me...you gotta git ghetto with the fried rice, I like my fried rice like I like my women, dark and salty. Their fried rice is a mandarin style I believe, very light and bland, so if you like your lovin light and bland, you probably will love it. 

The woman at the counter is old school, she don't play, she will mean mug you in a new york minute. Her Canton-English is sometimes hard to understand, she can be abrasive and if you are too slow she will wave her hand at you and walk away until she is ready to come back....I think I'm in luv. She gets it right, she does it fast and I tip her well.

Chinese broccoli is to-die-for, won ton soup is 7 out of 10, whole fried fish is crackin. The food is not bad at all...Check it out!
author: Jim L.

description: This is an acceptable place to stop when I'm short on time but still want some quick, no frills Chinese food in this neighborhood. The food is surprisingly good, the service fast, groups are easily facilitated and the atmosphere casual.
author: Michael J.

description: I've been here three times, and the last two times have only been because this place is so close to my apartment.  It is cheap, but the food is meh.  The place does have sports playing on a flat screen pretty much every time I walk by, so that's a plus, but the food could be better.  Service is fine.
author: Vitaliy D.

description:
Great deals on really good Chinese food. 

My absolute favorite food item from anywhere I've ever been is the Hung To Yee Won Ton soup from this place. It's a soup with imitation crab meat, egg, vegetables, and fried won ton. I always order one when eating or taking out from here. I kind of want one now. 

The other beef, pork, fish, and veggie dishes are done very well and priced very reasonably. 

It's a pretty small place, but I call in my orders to go about half the time anyways.
author: Calvin P.

description:
OK, apparently my DC (dining companion) and I ordered THE wrong items on the menu.

Lunch March 2009
- Mixed Vegetable Lo Mein less than $7
mostly celery and two pieces frozen carrot, excess water chestnuts and the slimy white gelatinous 'sauce' (& some ok broccoli)  - thank god for chili hot sauce ; portion big enough for two
- Spring Onion pancake less than $4
horrible! deep fried this morning and left to sit, dipping sauce had a undefinable flavor
- Lemon Chicken less than $8
my DC said, after a couple of bites, "this sauce is canned, I can actually taste the #10 metal". no veggies, just a heap of chicken and rice. rice portion big enough for three, chicken for two.

It smelled really enticing while I was waiting for him and the rice plates I saw go by looked good, so my expectations were solid. Plus the reviews were positive. But, if you are a vegetarian, the options are slim and if not, you can only apparently expect strip mall, small town quality.
author: Miel H.

description:
Great menu choices!  Fresh and Fast service!  And my number one choice for neighborhood Chinese!!!
They have delicious clay-pot dishes, try them!  This is the kind of good food you would expect to eat while in main-land China.

Great location in lower heights, but not so good if you're driving.  

Friendly staff, they make recommendations if you'll like to try something new and different - a big deal for me!
author: Yamil A.

description:
Do the Chinese eat the legs, head, and shell of shrimp?  I cant tell after getting this meal.

The portions are large and its the good cheap chinese food you get in 50 other shops around town.  I tracked this down based on a review of bargain eats in town through the Chronicle.  I got the steamed pot stickers, S&P shrimp, and won ton soup.  This place was destined for 3 stars and a nice write up but the prep locked it out of that bracket.  They hooked up a ton of pot stickers and the won ton is big and tasty.  Then came the entre.  

Its a good thing I stuffed my face with the stickers bc this entre was a pain in the ass to get to.  They, the chefs, took a giant fist of breaded shrimp, fried them up, salt, pepper, jalapenos, green onion... sounds tasty right?  Not when it takes you 35 minutes to 1. rip their heads off 2. rip their legs off 3. peel off their shells which sucks on lousy cheap shrimp 4.  then go grays anatomy on their backs and de-veins their poop shoot.  Why even apply any breading or spices if all of the shit is destined to be tossed when you clean and prep the damn shrimp?  I didnt like anatomy in high school and I still dont like it now.  The breaded heads and beedy eyes will haunt me tonight in the digestive war which is destined to go down.

So if you go, ask that they prep the shrimp propper, otherwise this place is ok and they have a flat screen tv with football on for your viewing pleasure while you wait.  That was snazzy and the staff were talking trash on TO which only added.  It'll probably knock to a 3 after the next trip.
author: Porfirio R.

description: Love the roast duck and the wonton soup.  Great food, inexpensive, fast service!
author: SF Y.

description:
everyone should try their famous Salt & Pepper Spare Ribs over rice and
Shrimp with Eggs Over Rice...both my fav dishes....yummy and great price for large portions...
i also recently tried the salt and pepper chicken wings and the chicken fried wonton soup...both are really delicious!!!
author: Laimei W.

description:
Gourmet Carousel is great for what it is--inexpensive Chinese comfort food.  They have most Chinese dishes that you can think of on the menu, and except for the seafood dishes, nothing is over $10.  I haven't been for lunch, but the portions were enormous.  Two entrees and soup definitely could have fed 3 people.  The service was also pretty standard Chinese restaurant service, plus our waiter spoke English, which was helpful. 

We had the pan fried flounder (cripy and delicious, although the sauce on top was thicker than what I'm used to), sizzling rice soup, and spicy eggplant with pork (absurdly huge dish).  I will definitely be back!
author: Cristina C.

description: Wor wont ton soup. 7 bucks and two full meals! it's got NO MSG and it's delicious!
author: Ed O.

description:
First of all, this place only got stars because we were able to find a parking spot right in front of it around dinner time and they had a big screen TV where we were able to catch the finale of Dancing With the Stars.

Other than that, the service was pretty lousy and my bf found a BUG on a piece of water chestnut in their seafood nest dish! They replaced the dish with a new one but we didn't get an apology or anything else. The food was very mediocre (trust me, I'm Chinese) and the best part of the meal was the fortune cookies at the end.
author: Karen Y.

description: Until last night, Gourmet Carousel was my favorite moderately priced restaurant.  The server, obviously, did not like me the minute I asked for water, no ice, with lemon.  Then, was perturbed when I returned the ''awful'' wontons my friend ordered, as well as the overly battered fried squid.  The ginger beef was good, but general cao's chicken was dried out meat and much too sweet.  The green beans I ordered were not even delivered to the table.  I have been to this restaurant many times and have brought many friends there, bringing them much money.  I will never return to this restaurant, nor bring any friends.  I recommend Red Jade restaurant on Church street for much friendlier service and very good moderately priced food.
author: Patrick B.

description: The pot stickers and won ton soup were warm, not hot.  The chow fun was too oily.  Lots of locals for lunch.  Can't beat the price.  For three of us, less than $20 and a small box of chow fun to take home.
author: Gail W.

description:
Wow, Im so surprised this place has such a low rating.
I love it! I dont know about the others but everytime I go there the food is great. Not greasy at all and plenty flavorful.
Prices are reasonable, but the service needs work.
Loyal Customer.
author: Judith F.

description: Old school lunchtime spot back in 00-01. Would eat here about 3 times a week at least when I worked in the city. Food is consistently good, cheap, and quick to be served. Favorite dish would have to be the S&P spareribs with white rice. Wor Won Ton soup was also great on a chilly SF day.
author: Anthony T.

description:
I haven't been to this place in many years, but remember it to be alright. So after an appointment downtown, I decided that we should try this place since we were on Pine Street anyway. Hungry Chinese food freaks please go here! 

I haven't been this excited about lunch since I discovered Kam's the first time. We all had rice plates (rice a la mode if you will) and the food was honestly piled on. I had the Chicken & Black Mushrooms. Lots of crisp veggies, chicken fillets, and not a whole lot of sauce. Just enough of it to coat everything and not drip off the plate. Wifey had the Sweet n Sour Pork that I didn't sample cause... it's Sweet n Sour Pork, OKAY? But it did look awesome, with huge pieces of everything it's suppose to have, and lots of it! What I really like is that you can customize your dish, like if it isn't on the menu... Just say I want beef with mustard greens with black bean sauce on rice and you got it, baby... for a couple more bucks. And... and... it gets better. This is a big lunchtime restaurant, that can turn over table after table so we were out of there in less than 40 minutes, which is great because all the daytime parking is 8 quarters per hour meters (we only had 6 quarters). There's more... yeah, it's cheap too. Geeze, if only the damn won ton soup had more won tons.

Best time to go? I'd say after 1pm. People are back from lunch, and there's meter parking opening up all over. Servers are still jacked from the lunch rush, and you get waited on like they're all bored to tears. I've seen their full dinner order portions... you just gotta go.

Gourmet Carousel is TOTALLY COOL!  Check it out! 
(They don't take Discover cards...)
author: Rick V.

description:
Not bad, for cheap chinese food.  I started coming to this place around the time of high school- almost 20 years ago. Amazingly enough they haven't really increased the prices of their food by that much. I usually just go there for the take out- about $4 for a rice plate. When I order I usually get the honey walnut prawns and the scrambled eggs with beef over rice-Good size portions.  Order by phone so you don't have to wait that long for pick up.

As I said it's not bad chinese food if you temper your expectations. I know it says gourmet in their name but don't expect Wolfgang puck cusine. 

Be aware that it's a small restaurant so if you have a large party coming in you might have to wait a big longer.
author: Bert T.

description:
I really want to like this place but its so hard. I have had cashew chicken and that was good but then one time I got some other chicken dish - gross. It had a sour taste. I honestly thought it might have gone bad, ew. 
After that experience I have become scared - real scared. I never want to taste that sour tasting chicken ever again. 
Although I want to like it since it seems so many people do - its hard.
author: Shawn P.

description:
If I were writing this review 3 or 4 years ago, it would be a 4 or 5 star review.  They use to have really good food, big portions at really good prices.  The last couple of times that we were there, we felt that they really cut back on their portion size and the food is just not the same.

Service is generally okay.  They do tend to get busy so if you have a larger party, I strongly suggest calling ahead and reserving a table.
author: Stella C.

description: Tasty food at a reasonable price. All my friends and I love the fried egg tofu there! As a Chinese, I would say the food there is pretty authentic, although some of them did get modified a little bit.
author: Suey L.

description:
Fast food, fair service, inexpensive, but I still don't get it.  Lines, at lunch.  Pretty filthy, too.  I still come here, too.  There are a lot of choices, but I guess it their ability to move people in/out.  All kinds of clientele; postal carriers, cops, construction workers, office workers...

I've been coming here for years, and probably will continue.  It must be something in the tea!
author: Collin W.

description:
Minus 1 star for their staffs and service.

Food here is pretty good and authentic, it can match up to the big chinese restaurants in Chinatown or Richmond/Sunset area.  Portions are generous and prices are reasonable.  Love their braised squab and garlic mustard greens.

I live around the block, too bad they do not deliver else I will be ordering from them 2-3 times a week.
author: Kate L.

description:
Former lower pac heights legends... (they've been around for a while) they've definately fallen from glory. I won't go over the menu items. I'm sure you're familiar.... (its as extensive as chinese gets too!) but i just want to express my sheer disappointment with the take out and service. the food is ok unless you ask for delivery..... but hey.. maybe i caught them on a bad day... or year....whatever.  

With other places like Ken's Kitchen upping the bar of quality and still lowering prices, these other guys got to keep up!
author: Eugene G.

description:
Let's just get straight to the point, yes?

Would I take a date here? No - the service and the decor would definitely embarrass any lady friend I brought here... but maybe this is a good place to take blind dates who you don't want to call you back??? hmm...

Would I get takeaway here if I was a cheap college student who couldn't be asked to cook anything? Yes - but barely... just get catering from someplace and thank yourself for saving 50 cents for the next few days, because Gourmet's prices may be great for SF, but this place wouldnt' last very long if it was anywhere else.
author: Andy A.

description: Came here last night with some friends who have been coming here for years, and was fairly pleased with the experience.  We shared the $38 "seafood special" (which my friends tell me used to be about $10 cheaper) and had more than enough food.  The meat on the whole fried flounder was good a moist, the salt and pepper prawns were fantastic, the clams in black bean sauce were tasty and not overcooked, and the "mixed seafood in a nest" was full of great scallops and squid.  I wouldn't say the meal was exceptional, but I certainly don't regret coming here.
author: Joshua W.

description:
This place is terrible. The food is not very good and the service is atrocious. I asked for Mongolian Beef, and it came with mushrooms. There was no mention of mushrooms in the menu, and since I hate mushrooms I asked the waiter if I can have the same dish without the mushrooms. 
His response? No. Since I didn't tell him ahead of time that I did not want mushrooms. Except that it never said anything about mushrooms on the menu. 
So I told him again, that I want a new plate with no mushrooms. So his solution? He gives me an empty plate and tells me "take out the mushrooms yourself."
At this point I was getting pretty pissed, so I told him to get me another order of Mongolian Beef with no mushrooms and he finally agreed. But considering how the food does not taste very good, I see no reason to ever come back here again.
author: Nitzan W.

description: Cheap, good, clean Chinese food with speedy service. Parking is hard to find in the area.
author: Linda N.

description:
Me and my wife lived around here for a few months and this was the closest place to eat Chinese food.  We ate here about once a week since the food was cheap and delicious. 

However, there are a few things that we hated about this place. The woman that greeted us out front which we nicknamed "The Pitbull" was always very rude to us on the phone and in person. My wife was actually scared to call her to put in our order since she was a bit "hostile".She had all the charm of a frothing wolverine yet not as cute. I understand she's trying to be efficient when speaking on the phone but perhaps she could let me put in my whole order before trying to hang up on me with a "uh huh..ok bye..." Perhaps if I could make just one suggestion for this place is don't put the person with the worst accent to pick up their phones and handle greeting customers (if you can even call it greeting. I think you'll have a better experience waiting in line at the airport shortly after 911 with a bottle of shampoo and a box cutter than wait here).

I've had so many horrible experiences with the service yet this one stood out. On one occasion she perhaps misunderstood my order on the phone. When I ordered beef with black bean for some reason they gave me beef tripe in black bean. Now I can stomach a lot of weird food however, certain things I draw the line..(like the inside of a cows stomach). I'm sure certain people just love the stuff but when I see that greyish skin matter in a black goopy soup it just reminds me of afterbirth. 

Anyhoo, I digress.. 

I walked back to the restaurant thinking "Well they must have misunderstood" and you know I was fully willing to pay for the new order since the stuff was so cheap. As soon as I told her that this was not what I wanted she went absolutely crazy. She started to accuse me that that's what I ordered and that she wasn't wrong. Literally yelling at me treating me like I just murdered her grandchildren. I couldn't really take this right after a hard day at work. Even when I told her I didn't care who's fault it was and that I'll pay for the right order she still went off on me.

All in all a good place to eat as long as you don't mind people treating you like your in a third world country market buying bak choi out of a van.
author: James Y.

description: There are GREAT things on the menu, and NOT so great things!  NEVER order Peking Duck, as it is ROAST duck with buns!  bones and all!!!  Great Roasted, but it is NOT Peking.   But the Won Ton Soup is AMAZINGLY FANTASTIC, as are the POTSTICKERS, the FRIED NOODLES say "Geen Mean"( served in a Pie Plate)---ask for prawns with it!  Curry chicken is FABULOUS, Love the BBQ RIBS and Roast Duck Noodle Soup!!!  (Good Roast Duck, but DEFINITELY is the same one they serve as Peking duck!!)  The food service at lunch is FRESH and well cooked.  We usually  eat lunch there 2 times a week  and  have dinner delivered at home at least once a week.  Prices are GREAT (whole lobster with ginger and green onions $12.95)  Servers  provide basic efficient service!  Owner is a hoot and fills every pot sticker and egg roll herself (No "Ling Ling" from Costco here!)She says she started the Delivery Service to keep her husband busy in the evenings!!  fun place with some  GREAT foods.  Enjoy!
author: S G.

description: Parking is crazy. The prices are quality of chinese food is above average. The portions are very generous and the employees are very friendly. Inside the restaurant there are several big screen tvs that are usually turned on to the local giants/49ers/warriors game. This is a decent place for both take out and dine in. If i lived near here, I would go here more often to satisfy my chinese food cravings.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Best chinese food in the city!!!! The food is inexpensive and you can fill your stomach on a $20. 

Gourmet Carousel has a variety of dishes to choose from, chicken, fish, pork, etc. The noodles, and chow main is heavenly. The food is fresh. The taste of the food is mouthwatering.

Lots of room to go eat out with your friends, family, or co-workers. 

A+, 5 Stars!
author: Michael K.

description:
This is a good place to get a lot of good food at lunch for a cheap price.  There are always lots of regular, returning Chinese customers, which I think is a good recomendation. 
One of us goes here for lunch at least once a week.  He really likes pork fried rice (don't criticize--that is what he likes) and Carousel gives him a huge pile of it with tiny shrimp and lots of other good stuff in with the rice.  The left-overs make 2 more lunches. I like the bitter melon soup that sometimes comes with dinner and I think the pot stickers are really well done. And another friend says the salted fish dishes are excellent, although that is not one of my favorites so I can't say.  Service is certainly competent, but it gets better and more friendly as you go more often and become a regular customer. 
Why not give this place a try?
author: C. A.

description:
Goodbye Gourmet Carousel

Gourmet is right down the street from me and I'm lazy, as a result I've probably eaten there a couple hundred times over the years.  They've never gotten me ill (that's 1 star), and Ive grown to like some of their dishes (that's the other star), but as others have pointed out, some of their food is horrible, eg. their Mongolian beef with mushrooms (see Nitzan W.'s review for details).

As a public service I was just going to pass along the list of dishes I've been able to safely order. Then it dawned on me, I'M DONE WITH THIS PLACE.

I'm done with:
The rude little old lady yelling "GOHMAAAAYYY!" when I phone in my order (see Lauren Y. or Josua P.); 
Being told the kitchen is closed when I call at 9:15; 
The nasty looks I get when I ask for a fork, napkin or some garlic chilli for my potstickers;
Never being charged the same price twice for a dish;
The questionable cleanliness of the kitchen and the cooking staff;
The occasional slimy gross-out dish that goes right to the trash;
All the deep fried and sugar coated crap making me fat, clogging my arteries and raising my blood sugar.

So... Goodbye Gourmet Carousel

******************************************

I'll be eating anywhere else, but for those of you who find yourselves at the Gourmet Carousel here's my safe ordering list:

Potstickers
egg roll (don't make the mistake of calling it a spring roll)
Salt n pepper chicken wings
bbq pork wonton soup 
Beef Steak Cubes w/ tender greens
Crispy Fried Chicken (half)
flounder fillet with salt and pepper
tomato beef chow mein
chicken chow mein
black bean sauce beef chow fun

Mu-Shu and Generl Tsou's were close calls but suffer from occasional quality control problems.
author: Jeff E.

description:
Yes, I will take verbal abuse when food is this cheap.

I used to live around the corner in this sterile neighborhood until I wised up and moved to Polk Gulch.  Gourmet was my neighborhood standby.  I must have eaten here at least 3 times a week for 6 months.  I've tried almost everything on the menu.  I will agree that many items aren't spectacular, but when you find the good ones, paying $3.75 for a meal large enough to feed two people is a gift from Buddha.

I will also agree that the service is a bit lacking.  The old lady at the front desk(who has been there for like ever) has an attitude that would challenge the fiercest drag queen.  She'll make you feel stupid, she'll tell you what's what.  She's awesome.  All I had to do is tip a little, and she would still give me attitude, but with an understanding that my business was appreciated.   Jesus chrsit, a little attitude is refreshing.  If I wanted a PF Chang's experience, I'd move to the Midwest.  Give me my food cheap and fast, and you can then talk back to me if you want.  Deep down, I believe she just has a wicked sense of humor; it's just hard to tell because the "humor" doesn't come with a smile.

So to get your money's worth plus some, and follow this guide on what to order:

BBQ Pork over rice - really great pork - huge portion, $3.75
Wonton Soup with BBQ Pork - at least 10 wontons! in a huge container of soup, $4.75
Sweet and Sour over rice - decent sweet and sour, $3.75
General Chow's chicken over rice - decent, $3.75
Whole Fried Fish

So put in your earplugs in or turn your iPod volume up if you can't take the abuse, and go get some cheap food people.
author: t l.

description: When I first started working at the hospital, my pals loved to go here. They called it "la china". Wanting to be cool with my new friends, I tried to find something here. I really, really did. But, listen - not even the steamed rice was edible. It smells bad and everything is flavored with this weird tasting sauce (liquid MSG? who knows.). Seriously, beware. If greasy cheap food is what you seek, do yourself an enormous favor and walk down to  Polk or to Tommy's Joynt.
author: Maria D.

description:
Talk amongst yourselves... I'll give you a topic: Gourmet Carousel, it's not gourmet, nor a carousel...discuss! You've got to love funny Chinese restaurant names. 

A few of the Chinese women in my office ordered lunch here yesterday and came to sit with me and my coworker in the office lunchroom. The food looked and smelled good, so we asked them where it was from. They told us about this place and that the food was good and cheap. Considering that these women eat tasty Chinese food every day, we took their word for it and went there for lunch today. 

My coworker and I decided to share a won ton soup ($3.50) and a combination chow mein ($5.50). We could have shared 1 dish and still had leftovers. The portions were huge and as the Chinese women told us, everything was cheap! We weren't able to finish either dish. The food was ok though. The won ton soup was pretty good, and could have fed 4 people. But the chow mein was... well, the more I thought about all the ingredients in the combination chow mein, the more I didn't like it. It was seriously a combination of all the 10 other chow mein dishes they had on their menu. It had chicken, beef, bbq pork, scallops, squid, tripe, shrimp, bok choy, broccoli, carrots, fried soggy fish that was probably cooked yesterday... all mixed up in a mound of noodles. I think I had 1 of each item before I decided to stop eating. I just couldn't stop thinking, did they just mix up all their leftovers from yesterday?

The service was not that great. My soup spoon had crusty bits of food on it, and so I asked for a new one. The lady seemed a bit annoyed. Then we asked for ice water and chili sauce, and that made her super annoyed. 

Should I have the desire to return, I will most likely order take-out, and stick with something safe, like mongolian beef with rice.
author: Connie C.

description: This place is awesome. The food is great. I love the sesame chicken, the shrimp fried rice, and the rice noodles. They give HUGE portions. And it's ridiculously cheap. The only downside is they dont deliver. A chinese place that doesnt deliver? that's a rarity...but you can order in and the food doesnt take very long to be ready. Great place for lunch.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I've read some of the negative reviews of this Cantonese restaurant, and with Gourmet Carousel, it's all about knowing what to order.  Which, yes, I know, at an excellent restaurant you should be able to order anything and be satisfied, but, this is not an excellent restaurant.  It is very tasty if you order the right food, and farely cheap.  For instance, the lo mein and chow mein are not so good.  And if you are looking for typical sesame chicken, they don't have it.  Their's is not covered in sauce, the sauce comes on the side.  Apparently that bothers some people.  BUT let me tell you, the salt and pepper crab is so delicious that if a close friend said to me 'Red, I am so hungry, but I am sick and tired of all the restaurants in my area, and I don't feel like making food, what should I do?"  I would send them straight to Gourmet Carousel for the salt and pepper crab.  It's that good.  Other things that are really good:

- Wrapped Chicken appetizer
- Salted egg with pork and mustard green soup
- Winter melon with diced pork soup
- Prawns in Lobster sauce
- Clams with ginger and scallions
- Chinese style beef steak cubes
- BBQ pork
- Scrambled egg and chinese sausage over rice *** REALLY GOOD.
So go, and order these yummy things.  You won't regret it.
author: Red F.

description: The food here is not bad but if you crave verbal abuse just try to phone in a take out order in the evening. There's a little old lady who answers the phone "GohmaAAy!" She treats me like I've stolen something from her but the cheap decent food is worth the unprovoked and almost comical rudeness. No fortune cookies fo' you!
author: Josua P.

description:
I'm going to round up and give this little hidden restaurant 4 stars. I had a great experience the 2nd time around, maybe cuz I came with recommendations. 

Here's what we had:
- Crab Clay Pot (not on the menu - you have to ask for it): Basically crab that's been steamed or boiled with soy seasoning and glass noodle. Definitely unique. You'll pay market price for the crab. They do come but up but you'll still have to work for your dinner.
- Egg and Shrimp: This is a homestyle dish rarely ordered (I would argue) by Chinese because it's something mom makes at home, but it was really good. Kinda like scrambled eggs with shrimp but lighter and with scallions and flavor.
- Salt Pepper Pork Ribs: Dry style fried pork w/ seasoning. Can't go wrong with this dish.
- Snow Pea Shoots: Ahhh yumm. So tender, and simply prepared with garlic. Seriously, the veggie itself is terrific.
- Sizzling Rice Soup: Just a fun clear broth soup that makes a sizzling entrance.
- Salted Fish Fried Rice: We tried this one with a little skepticism, but were all pleasantly surprised. Preserved salted fish is stir fried and imparts flavor to a typical rice dish. It wasn't fishy unless you got a big chunk. Otherwise, tasty!

And the meal ends with juicy slices of oranges. The authentic way to end a Chinese meal. And only $13pp.
author: Cindy W.

description:
could this be the place i've been looking for ever since i set foot in this town...?  it was great!  yee!  my palate is trained in toronto, the chinese food capital of north america, so the only things that get into my mouth are things i *actually* like... 

we got the special family dinner - my favourites were: 
- shredded scallop soup - very generous with the scallop, verrrrry tasty;
- dried oyster with lettuce - everyone loved this (me too);
- peking duck (with 12 buns) (the best part was one dining companion's comment to another as she split the bun open: "ya lookin' for a maaaan in there?"  no men inside, we discovered, but i loved that melt-in-your-mouth thing about the steamed bun.  hmm?)
- crispy fried prawns - just eat the whole damn thing (thank you, parents, for teaching me how to eat right).

i see the place has a very unenthusiastic rating, but my experience here was great.  the only suck-ass thing is the parking -- but it opens up after 7 pm on the nearby streets.  happy eating!
author: Lenita M.

description: This place is great if you only have $4.50 and want a plate of food that will last you two days.  I always order the rice plates from the back of the menu.  I live on the same block as this place so I always just get take out so i don't know about delivery but it only takes them about 10 minutes for take out (I don't know if that's a good thing or a bad thing).  Make sure you know what you want to order when you call though because if you don't the lady might hang up on you.  Basically it's cheap, greasy, fast, and filling but that's about it.
author: Jessica H.

description: Gourmet Carousel is right down the street from my apartment in Pac Heights.  After reading the reviews on Yelp describing the cleanliness and the lower prices, my boyfriend and I decided to try it out.  We trudged our way out there the day after Christmas and was pleasantly surprised to see that it was open after the normal lunch hour.  I ordered the Chicken Chow Mein and the boyfriend ordered a bbq pork and roasted duck combo.  The food was good, but nothing amazing.  I might return because it is in my hood, but I've had better.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
oh gourmet carousel.  

it's a good thing i live next door (no, not the ugly dirty green building), because my roommates and i are fully addicted.  

this is THE default take out place when we run out of groceries, have the drunk munchies, or when i miss my mom's cooking.  and that's saying a lot, because my mom is a bomb ass cook.

i must admit, im not so into their americanized chinese dishes, though i do have a soft spot for their singapore noodles (a big ol' vat of curry flavored deliciousness for under 4 bucks).

their traditional chinese dishes are the shining stars.  i love their ginger scallion chicken, their squash and vermicelli clay pot, their braised tofu, their snow cabbage and pork noodle soup.  even their complimentary soup, all brown and boney and herbally.  

it just tastes like home.  soul food.  

... now if only they had congee.
author: Helen L.

description: I visited the Gourmet Carousel on a Sunday night. around 7pm. The place was packed. I thought to myself that this must be a good restaurant. The food was mediocre. Being a vegetarian, I was able to find some menu items I could eat (crossed my fingers that the menu items I selected were not prepared with some animal product.)
author: Victor I.

description: One of the best chinese food in the area for the price you're paying. The salt and pepper porkchops are very good, though there isn't much salt and pepper on them to begin with. It's fine though because you can just add some later. Their fillet fish with black bean sauce is very good. They use rock cod (though cat fish is usually used in most places i've been to) to make this dish. There is also the abalone and mushroom dish which is very light to the stomach. All of there dishes taste fresh and well prepared. There are no rancid smells or tastes that are present in some other chinese restaurants i've been to. My parents have been coming here for about 20 years now and have introduced me here several years back. I really like this place, and i believe it deserves way more than just 3 stars...
author: Jeffrey L.

description: a bud recommended this place. unfortunately, they may have changed their head cook by the time we got here. this was a while ago, the restaurant was busy. our food had too much oil in it. the portions were good but didn't look that appetizing cuz we expected better.
author: Victor G.

description: Excellent basic chinese food at great prices!  I recommend to eat in, as the portions tend to be bigger ...a greater deal!
author: Richard M.

description:
I've been here quite a few times, always take out.  Fine value.  Really good pot stickers, squid with ginger and scallions, solid chow mein, but what really stands out and I find surprising is hardly mentioned in the reviews I've scanned is the God-like roast duck: lots more pieces than most restaurants serve, and what's more, 3/4 of them actually have meat on them, delicious, tender, almost paté-like texture.

Lame alert: Smallish, unsucculent prawns are the epitome of mediocrity.

MIA: Belligerent but fun little Aqua-net headed matriarch who used to command the front desk, the phone and of course, the money, all the money.  Favorite nostalgic phone conversation:

     Me:   One more thing, no tofu in the chow mein, please-
     Her:  No tofu in chow mein!!!  We don't put tofu in chow mein!!!
     Me:   OK, it's just last time I had some tofu in my chow-
     Her:   No tofu in chow mein!!!  We don't put tofu in chow mein!!!
author: Ultiminio P.

description: Some birds were created for this earth just to be eaten.  The Squab is a perfect example.  I've had a lot of Squab in my life and Carousel's right up there with the best of them.
author: Brent N.

description:
I was a regular at this place, then got sick of it after eating it too much, and I didn't approve the fact they raised the prices.
But can still get meals for under $5. So I get dinner and leftovers for lunch tommorrow for $5. 

Taste wise, I've had better to say the least. But the low price keeps me coming back, whenever I'm trying to keep my costs down in this city.
author: S. S.

description: Good inexpensive Chinese.  Less Americanized than most.  You get what you pay for so no Niman Ranch on the menu, but tasty meals piled high on the plate.
author: M M.

description:
Yes I've had better Chinese food, but for the price, it's really quite good.
Bottomline, its cheap, the restaurant is clean, and the quality of what I've eaten so far, well exceeds what you are paying for. Its very casual and a little old school so don't come here expecting an elegant dining experience. Come here with low maintenance friends to get a really reasonably priced family style meal.

Yes some of the staff is inattentive and  can even seem a little surly at times, but the service is more old school Chinese. They are more about trying to be efficient than giving you warm fuzzies. I actually find it kind of funny, and again, this place is cheap, so don't expect 5 star service.

Yes the decor is lacking but its not dirty and the flat screen tv is bonus.
Its definitely not a first date kind of place. 

Salt and Pepper shrimp come with head and tail because for Chinese its more to show the freshness. The shrimp aren't really deveined either, so if that really bothers you, don't order shrimp, but it does taste good.
I'd recommend ordering from that one sheet family menu, if you have 3 or more people. No not the first page of the bigger menu, its the laminated one that has Chinese on one side.

 As a rule of thumb for any Chinese place, I usually order from the Chinese menu (sometimes in Chinese on the wall) if there is one because I hate to say it but many times we treat our people or those that recognize...a little better. That and many of the cooks come from HK or the mainland with training in more authentic dishes, so they aren't as good or take as much pride at making Americanized dishes.
That being said I've never ordered some of the more common staples here like sweet and sour anything, Mongolian, beef or potstickers so I can't say if its good or bad.
Their fish is pretty good if you don't mind it with the head on -Again..the whole freshness thing. Steamed or pan fried with green onion, both pretty good.
author: Pete L.

description: Decent, super cheap Chinese food.  I used to live about 150 feet from this place and at one point was eating their pork fried rice at least once a week (takeout -- I've never actually eaten in the restaurant).  Why? Because it was tasty and they gave you a big tub of the stuff for only $3.95.  This was like manna from heaven for a starving student.  I also frequently enjoyed the eggplant with spicy pork, and the chow fun was good, but EXTREMELY greasy.   One word of caution: when ordering takeout,  be prepared for Soup Nazi-like treatment from the lady who answers the phone, should you not be sure of what you want to order.  She has no time for your indecisiveness.
author: Andrew E.

description: Got take-out one night.  Food is pretty good and not greasy, but let's just say the service is very brusque.  The woman had little patience with me when I ordered over the phone (had a couple questions ont he menu).  When we picked up our order, we asked for chopsticks.  The hostess gave us 1.  We asked for another pair.  She was not happy when she gave us another.  Does she expect us to share???
author: Mitzi C.

description: Authentic Chinese food, great for take out, fast, large portions and reliable.  The deep fried won ton soup with roast duck is excellent.  Also recommend the Hong Kong style crispy noodles.
author: Ed D.

description:
clean, cheap, delicious

i never thought i'd ever use all three words in the description of a san francisco chinese restaurant, ever! 

[usually it's best two out of three, "clean" being the least used]

and when i say cheap, i mean CHEAP. you can get full for $4, and completely bloated for $5. bring friends and go to town.
author: Charles C.

description: Gourmet Carousel is the place to go to get pretty decent Chinese take-out food.  And pricewise, it's a good deal too.  Each time we've tried the walnut prawns, mu-shu pork, pea sprouts, and broccoli beef, we had more than enough leftovers to last for a few servings.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
This is really a San Francisco landmark in my opinion. It epitomizes everything an American Chinese food restaurant should be, and sterotypes it in almost every way. Coming from a Jewish decent, we love Chinese food. It is somehow in our genes to crave it. Groumet Carousel (GC) satisfies on many levels. The only reason I neglected to give it 5 starts are because it does not deliver and becaue I think some of the items could use a bit less oil. 
   Everytime I go to this place it is busy with a good assortment of people. The usuals are Asians (always a good sign) and those connoisseurs of cravingly palatable Chinese cuisine. Even though the menu is very large, I seem to be ordering the same things all the time. The dishes there have very short names, and I only order what I don't know if I am in the mood for gambling. I have no idea what I am going to get when I order blindly, which is under certain circumstances a good thing. My favorites there are the Egg Foo Young, and most of their vegetable dishes. There have some interesting dishes there as well, such as the glazed shrimp with pecans. Not very asiany, but still delicious. Always the kicker, the prices are really reasonable there. No dish is over 6-7 bucks, with a nice healthy portion. And I am really one to be pick about portions. I really hate the fru-fru, pretentious, small sized, over priced, BS meals that you get in this city. I don't know what anorexic crowd these meals are designed for, but I will not put up with it. Ariel is fully satisfied with this place and will keep going back.  I have to say that last Christmas I strolled over there for the food, and now it is my official Winter Egg Foo Young wonderland!
author: Ariel A.

description: This place is like the soup nazi...they don't fuck around. They're less than helpful, but the food is sooooooo good. The dishes are dirt cheap and come in huge portions. I highly recommend the singapore noodles, and the salt and pepper pork spare ribs. I eat here at least once a week, its amazing, and I'm totally addicted.
author: brendan g.

description: I don't live in SF anymore but I went here all the time as a kid, we lived up the street. I go here every now and then because the food is amazing!!! It's by far the best! Yes the staff is rude but I ignore them, give me my food and leave me alone! Haha
author: Minority Critic C.

description: My favorite Chinese pickup place in the city. My top choice is the beef stew over rice. Cheap, fast, and delicious.Perfect for pickup. I highly recommend this spot and consider it one of the best I've had in the city.
author: Anderson L.

description:
avoid this chinese restaurant like the plague. dishes are bland, greasy, and just plain BAD!!!

if you're hungry hit the takeout counter at wholefoods, trust me you will be happier!
author: Christian S.

description: Eh, this place left very little desire for me to want to come back.  The 'Onion Pancakes' were interesting and quite nice, however, what fried food isn't enjoyable......?  The 'Tofu & Vegetables' was just, blah and slimy, the 'Eggplant' was nice though too, but it is hard for eggplant to not be good however it is prepared.  Service is prompt, food is very cheap and servings are huge, it's worth a shot to give it a try......
author: Steven K.

description:
OK, this is my first review, bear with me.  I have been in SF for a week and have been dying to have Sesame Chicken.  And everywhere I travel I order it as a reference point of what I'm used to.  I check out the reviews on CitySearch and find Gourmet Carousel.  The first time I attempted to go couldn't find parking and gave up.  The second time, I found parking and went in to order my desire to go.  The order is under $10 so they won't take a credit card, so I add egg rolls, also it doesn't come with rice, it's extra $.  I get my order fairly quickly and ask if there is sweet n sour sauce for the egg rolls, the lady nods yes, and then a guy chases me outside and hands me a little plastic conainer with, what I think, is SnS sauce.  I drive to Crissy Field and find a nice park bench to eat my, much awaited, meal.
The egg rolls are crispy, greasy and not much in them, and I'm dipping them into the sauce the guy gave me although they had their own little container of sauce in the bag.  I didn't order the rice but they gave me some.  But my shock came when I looked at the Sesame Chicken!!  It was just the chicken, batter fried, dry, nothing else!  ???  Not a sesame seed in sight!  I called the restaurant and told them what I had found and they said that it came that way.  I said where are the sesame seeds, the sauce?  I was informed that the seeds were there in the batter.  (I found maybe two).  And the sauce the guy gave me was the sesame sauce.  I guess you pour this tiny amount of sauce over the chicken and it becomes transformed?  Well, I had used that to dip my egg rolls in, still no sesame seeds.  Now I have a little container of SnS sauce and I'm dipping my greasy pieces of chicken in it.  The batter is not quite cooked through and some of the batter pieces didn't even have chicken in them.  BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!!
They have a huge selection of things on their menu so I may try them again, based again on the other reviews I have read, but I will eat in next time.  The experience was the only negative in an otherwise beautiful day watching the sailboats at the marina.
author: Paula W.

description: I tried their Tomato Beef chow mein and had it delivered.   It was absolutely drenched in oil.  Literally glistening in the light.  Why do they use soo much?  They use way too many onions in their Tomato Beef chow mein and it was not sweet at all.  Literally, it should have been called Onion chow mein.  Tasteless.
author: Spiffy K.

description: Sadly, I just moved away from this place. It used to be a glorious sweatpants walk right down the street. It's great for quick take out...but I'd have to agree, the lady who answers the phone is a little rough around the edges. Know what you want before you call. Well worth it for some goooood chinese food, though.
author: Quinn D.

description:
I don't know what restaurant these other people are raving about, but I've gotta certify this place as an unholy crap-factory. Everything was layered in a thick film of grease and was generally untastey. We got kung-pow chicken and mongolian beef. The chicken in the kung pow were these little overcooked pellets of meat that looked they were left over from the purina factory and I think I tasted hoof in the beef dish. 

And OH the service!!! We asked our waitress to split the check. She looked down at the floor and said "split the check?!" like we wanted her to spit shine our shoes. 

We had tons of leftovers so we got them to go and left them on a mailbox for some poor unsuspecting transient.
author: Tim O.

description: It had been about 8-9 years since I last ate here.  My recollection of the place was fond but the Yelp reviews gave me pause.  For good reason.  This was really mediocre Chinese food.  The Chicken Chow Mein was heavily laden with bean sprouts and the pieces of chicken were like contorted toothpicks sprinkled over the dish.  The potstickers had a foul, off taste.  The Kung Pao Chicken had stale tasting peanuts and too many water chestnuts.  When I went to pick up my order I was also disturbed to see they had a rating of only 90/100 on their last health department visit.  I won't be back any time soon.
author: J. O.

description: This is a very quirky little place. The food is good old mainstream American-Chinese - and very inexpensive. The servings are large and the service minimal. Go to eat big on a budget.
author: Nan B.

description: From the outside, this place is not much for looks, but once inside, carpeting, table cloths, dark wood, and mirrors astonish one.!  I stopped in last night and had some excellent Cantonese cuisine.  The pot stickers, a little doughy, are excellent and crispy golden with a wonderful ground pork, ginger, and cabbage filling; perfect topped with a little vinegary and soy sauce on top.  The sweet and sour rock cod fillet is crispy and greasless with a well balanced sweet and sour sauce and fresh pineapple, bell pepper, and onion.  I loved the free small order of winter melon soup with fresh, soft winter melon (a little bidder but good,) pork, and vegetables in a savory broth.  The steamed rice is excellent; not soggy but firm.  My mother loved her chicken with green beans which I will have to try.  For $26.00, we definitely got our money's worth.  The service is friendly and efficient.  So, for excellent Cantonese cuisine at rock bottom prices with friendly service in a clean atmosphere, Gourmet Carousel cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: great for dining in or pick up.  place is cheap and you get big meaty or veggie portions, staff is friendly and fast.  4 stars due to the beef chow fun just being plain awful. :shocked: everything else though is yummy especially the crispy chicken with shrimp chips, roast duck won ton noodles soup, beef stew, etc.
author: Pickle R.

description: Best Chinese food in the city. Been coming here for about 20 years. Best wonton soup I've ever had. Great, friendly service, and the mean old lady at the front desk isn't so bad once you get to know her. Don't be fooled by the look. The food portions are gargantuan, with a great price that you can't find anywhere else. It is great since some friends live right across the street. You should get: crab, wonton soup, green onion pancakes, potstickers, lobster, chicken chow mein, chicken chow fun, etc! Not the fake Americanized Chinese food. This is pretty much the real deal.
author: Beth L.

description: I ate here many times over the years.  Most of the time, I would give them an overall 3.5 star.  However, there were times where I would give them a 2 star and at other times  a 4 star.  I tried them for lunch and dinner on numerous occasions.  The quality of the food seems to vary depending upon what day of week you are there and whether you are there for lunch or dinner.  I can only guess that they probably have 2 or 3 different chef working different shifts resulting in an inconsistent quality with above average results most of the time.   As a Chinese who ate at hundreds of Chinese restaurants, I would say that their Yee Fu Wonton is better than most Chinese restaurant.  Another above average dish which many Chinese will generally like but which many Westerners may dislike is the Salted Fish and Chicken Fried Rice.
author: Greg L.

description: mediocre food at best. rude staff. and the bill? you better do the calculations yourself cause they usually charge you a dollar or two more than it really should be, especially on take outs.
author: Audrey L.

description: not too bad of a place to go if you're craving for some chinese food. please DO NOT, i repeat DO NOT order the salted pork chop/ribs. it's just too dry, chewy & over fried! i'm glad we have ordered the rock cod with sweet & sour sauce (which wasn't bad at all) so i was dipping my pork  on the sauce...heheheeh...their vegetables are very good and love the yang chow fried rice. big portion, cheap and the place is pretty clean.
author: Nelle A.

description: this spot has really great beef chow fun.  really great!  i don't know if it is worth a super special trip to the hood but since my first job in sf was right down franklin from here we ended up here quite a bit.  the food is pretty good, but not the best by a long shot (this is SF after all).  but i can't say i would mind if gourmet carousel moved to san diego for a little while.
author: becky k.

description: I'll concede this place is cheap and a good size for groups. But the ambience and flavors remind me of '70s California Chinese. Both are a little bland. Also, personal preference, I don't really like the use of celery in Chinese dishes. I supposed I'd still come, though, if I lived a a block away and could find those "gems" other folks have mentioned.
author: Midori S.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants in SF.  Almost everything on the menu is authentic and yummy and inexpensive.  take-out is a great option.  faves (and i have many) are whole steamed fish, crab with garlic and scallions, seafood bird nest, mandarin spareribs, tomato beef chow mein, salt and pepper pork, mu shu anything
author: Christine Y.
